against marijuana, but if there is not sufficient consensus to
obtain that, then I think the way to go is to permit a more
Federal approach so States can make their own decisions within
the framework of the Federal law and so we are not just
ignoring the enforcement of Federal law.
Now, I have not studied specifically the STATES Act, but I
have just circulated it through the Department for comment. I
think that is the process it is in now. Once we get those
comments, we will be able to work with you on any concerns
about the STATES Act, but I would much rather that approach,
the approach taken by the STATES Act than where we currently
are.
Senator Murkowski. Well, I think you will have a group of
folks over here that would like to work with you, would like to
work with the Department on that.
VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN ACT (VAWA)
Let me move to the Violence Against Women Act (VAWA) and
Special Domestic Violence Criminal Jurisdiction. In the 2013
reauthorization of VAWA, we recognized Tribal Special Domestic
Violence Criminal Jurisdiction that allowed Tribes to prosecute
non-Native domestic violence offenders in Tribal courts, and
this was for a limited class of offenses.
TRIBAL AFFAIRS
So just last week, the House passed its reauthorization
vehicle that expands this jurisdiction to a broader class of
sexual assault and domestic violence offenses as well as crimes
against children and assaults on Tribal police officers.
The vehicle there, the reauthorization vehicle, also allows
for a pilot project that is specific to Alaska Native villages
that have 75 percent or greater Native population to exercise
this jurisdiction. I think that all these provisions in the
House bill are a step in the right direction.
You and I have had discussion about the issues of just
protection in general in outlying areas of very remote parts of
my State, where we really have got to be thinking outside of
the box when it comes to how we provide for protection.
So allowing for these limitations based on jurisdiction are
really, really hard when you have women and children that are
vulnerable.
So I am hoping that we can continue to work with you on
these jurisdictional issues. I am hopeful that we will have a
chance to bring you up to the State so we can get you out into
some of these villages, see how these Tribal courts are
functioning, and again better explore the opportunities to
provide for a level of safety.
I do appreciate you including the 5 percent Tribal set-
aside from the Crime Victims Fund. I think that this is going
to make a difference, but if you can comment in any way on this
aspect of Tribal jurisdiction and what it might mean for
domestic violence protection?
Attorney General Barr. Well, I think Alaska Native women
face unacceptably high levels of violence in very remote areas,
and I have actually scheduled a trip up to Alaska specifically
to visit some of these communities.
Senator Murkowski. Good.
Attorney General Barr. And so I would approach this with a
great deal of sympathy for the need to think outside of the box
and to do something that is effective in protecting this
vulnerable population, and I am prepared to work with you to
try to fashion something that will work.
Senator Murkowski. Well, I appreciate that, and also
working on the murdered and missing indigenous women's
initiatives that we are working on----
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Murkowski [continuing]. I look forward to that as
well too and welcome you to the State.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Senator Moran. Senator Manchin.
Senator Manchin. Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman.
Thank you, Mr. Attorney General, for being here and your
service.

AFFORDABLE CARE ACT (ACA)
The other thing I wanted to say is on the ACA. I think my

OPIOIDS
Senator Manchin. I am just very much concerned about that.
West Virginia has been ravaged by an opioid epidemic, and I
have supported by the special agents in charge of the region of
FBI office and their efforts to catch the largest distributors.
It is now well known that a single pharmacy in West
Virginia town of Kermit, a little town of Kermit, less than 400
people, received shipments of roughly 9 million--9 million pain
pills in this little town.
It is less well known that the DEA, Drug Enforcement
Agency, explicitly requested to Congress to help in amending
the existing statute to restore the authority to intercept
these illegal shipments.
So my question would be, do you still support amending the
immediate suspension order standard from substantial likelihood
to probable cause, which gives the DEA the clout to stop these
horrific shipments into our little State and all over this
rural America? Have you looked at that, or has it come----
Attorney General Barr. I have not looked at it. I would
support it. I do not know if the Department has taken a
position on that, but anything that will strengthen
enforcement----
Senator Manchin. We need all our legal eagles there. We
really need help here, and we need your support on putting it
back to probable. Basically, it is a very contentious change
that went in, substantial, which basically stopped the DEA cold
in its tracks going after and stopping these shipments before
they hit the streets.
Attorney General Barr. Let me look into that, but
obviously, I want to----
Senator Manchin. It is very, very important. It is
tremendous harmful to our States.
FOREIGN INVESTMENT/ESPIONAGE
My final one would be on foreign investment, sir. I am very
much concerned about what is going on, and I am concerned about
the attempts of foreign countries to make investments and gain
control over certain American critical technologies and
industries, whether it is financial, the things that we see
going on and the investments they are making. And sometimes
they have a front for this, and we have not engaged it.
So is there any law enforcement agency or anyone in your
Department keeping track of the types of actions taken by
foreign countries that could be harmful? Artificial
intelligence, machine learning, on and on and on, that we know
what they have been doing through espionage and sabotage.
Attorney General Barr. Yes. The FBI is at the forefront of
that effort. This budget seeks enhancements of $18 million to
their program of watching for this kind of economic espionage
and also intelligence, but also another $5 million for
monitoring and upgrading our ability to review transactions in
the Committee on Foreign Investment in the United States
(CFIUS) process too.
Senator Manchin. We want to work with you on that. We have
a tremendous concern, and we know what is going on. The only
thing I would say, that just a simple--in West Virginia, they
understand that if we are not allowed to go into China and
Russia and have investments or ownerships or control over any
of their critical infrastructure, why in the world do we allow
them to come and use a front in order to have control when the
Government basically is controlling their----
Attorney General Barr. Right. This is one of my highest
priorities.
Senator Manchin. Thank you. It is very, very much a
concern. Thank you.
Senator Moran. Senator Capito.
Senator Capito. Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and thank you, Mr.
Attorney General, for your service.
BUREAU OF PRISONS (BOP) STAFFING/HIRING
I wanted to ask about the Bureau of Prisons. During the
shutdown, obviously our correctional officers and staff
remained on duty, but we have Hazelton in West Virginia. We
have had several murders at Hazelton. We have had--and I am
sure Senator Manchin has the same thing. We have had complaints
from staffing that there are staffing shortages, that it is not
safe for our correctional officers. They are being asked to
perform different duties maybe than what they are originally
assigned for.
And in the budget, there is a funding reduction for
correctional officer staffing and salaries in the budget. Could
you help me square with that, and this is a national problem
that you are finding across the BOP?
Attorney General Barr. I think this is an area where we
have stumbled, and I will tell you. I have been looking into
this. This has been very frustrating to me because I have
always supported Bureau of Prisons in the past and think it is
a great organization, and if we are going to have people
incarcerated, we have to make sure they are incarcerated under
proper conditions.
Senator Capito. Right.
Attorney General Barr. The way I look at it, our authorized
level is good and adequate. It is that we are 4- to 5,000
people short of our authorized level.
Now, why has that come about? A part of that overall number
may be because of the hiring freeze, which I lifted yesterday.
Senator Capito. Oh, good.
Attorney General Barr. But those slots were really in the
regional offices and in the headquarters. The shortages out in
the prison facilities themselves were not affected by the
freeze.
I think what it is is, frankly, bureaucracy, and I do not
say this in a bad sense. Just the way these organizations go
about bringing in people, they leave much too much of a lead
time.
So the way it works in the Bureau of Prisons, if a person
at this level leaves, then the next person moves up, and they
do not start the process of hiring a new person until sort of
everyone has taken a new chair.
Senator Capito. Right.
Attorney General Barr. And then they go out, and it takes
months and months and months to get that person on board. That
makes no sense because every year, we lose 2,600 of these
correctional officers.
So my view is we just have to turn on the spigot and just
keep these new entry-level people coming in at a rate where we
are going to be able to get up to and maintain our enacted
level. So I think this is largely a snafu by the Department,
and that is how I interpret it, and that is how I am
approaching it.
Senator Capito. Well, thank you.
I am glad to hear what you have said in terms of getting
more people because the ratios are going up, and certain
situations can be very dangerous for the officers that are
working there. And then that discourages people from wanting to
stay.
Attorney General Barr. Right.
Senator Capito. It is a tough job.
Attorney General Barr. It is tough.
Senator Capito. So anything we can do to help on that.
OPIOIDS
I would like to ask you about the opioid crisis. When you
came to visit me, we talked about this. It is just a scourge on
our Country, but really in our particular region.
I know that you are increasing the budget in that area, but
are there areas that are working better on the disruption part
of the drug interdiction that you think we need to put more
emphasis on rather than spread out as far and wide as we are?
Attorney General Barr. I really cannot say that.
I think where we are, we are having a lot of success, so I
think it is taking that and reproducing it elsewhere.
And, as you know, we have essentially a two-pronged
strategy. One is the legal drugs that have been overprescribed
and diverted and created this population of people who are
addicted, and we have to push that down to a smaller group.
I know Senator Manchin mentioned that hotspot. We have a
lot of resources now focused on doing that, and I think we are
going to be announcing some major successes in doing this.
Then the other is going after the big operations in
Mexico----
Senator Capito. Right.
Attorney General Barr [continuing]. And then the local
distribution. We are adding $254 million of High Intensity Drug
Trafficking Areas (HIDTA) program money to our budget, where it
will be administered through DEA as well.
Senator Capito. Well, I think when we see the squeeze-down
on legal prescriptions that are then used illicitly, that is
when heroin and the fentanyl and all of that comes in, and now
it is crystal meth that is coming in--
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
SPECIAL COUNSEL MUELLER'S INVESTIGATION
Senator Capito [continuing]. Across the southern border.
I just want to--as a clarification, as a non-lawyer here,
we hear--this is the Mueller Report--we hear a cry on Capitol
Hill to release the entire report. I just want to reemphasize
what you said, stated to Senator Kennedy for those of us who
are non-legal.
That would be very unprecedented and damaging to just put
the whole thing out there and an unreasonable request. Am I
stating that correctly?
Attorney General Barr. I do not know if it would be
unprecedented since I am not really sure what happened in the
Watergate situation. I know the report came out 50 years later,
I think.
Senator Capito. And from a legal----
Attorney General Barr. It is essentially unprecedented, I
would say.
Senator Capito. All right. Thank you.
Senator Moran. Thank you.

Senator Van Hollen. Yes.

SPECIAL COUNSEL MUELLER'S INVESTIGATION
Let me ask you with regard to the Mueller Report in your
March 24 letter. You say that Mueller set out evidence on both
sides of the question that leaves unresolved what the Special
Counsel views as ``difficult issues of law in fact concerning
whether the President's action and intent could be viewed as
obstruction.'' Do you agree with the assessment of Bob Mueller
that the evidence is in fact presenting difficult issues of law
in fact on those matters?
Attorney General Barr. I am not going to comment on it
until the report is out and everyone is singing from the same
sheet.
Senator Van Hollen. Mr. Attorney General, I am not--but I
am not asking you for what is in the report.
You sent a letter to the United States Congress that
included something, which was a principal conclusion, which was
not a conclusion reached by the Mueller Report. You indicated
that they did not exonerate the President. You did.
And so I am asking you whether you agree with Mueller that
there were difficult issues of law in fact in making that
assessment?
Attorney General Barr. That is not a question I really can
answer until I think----
Senator Van Hollen. Well, you did it--but you made-- you
looked at the report, right? And you looked at the evidence of
the report, and you made a decision. And you said that the
President is not guilty of criminal obstruction of justice.
I am asking you, in your review of the report, did you
agree with Mueller that there were difficult issues of law in
fact?
Attorney General Barr. I am going to give my reaction and
comments about the report after the report is out.
Senator Van Hollen. But you put your view of the report out
there on this issue of obstruction of justice, right? Nobody
asked you to do that.
Attorney General Barr. I did not put my view of the report.
Senator Van Hollen. Well, you put your assessment on--you
made a conclusion on the question of obstruction of justice
that was not contained in the Mueller Report, and I am simply
asking you, when you looked at the evidence, did you agree with
Mueller and his team that there were difficult issues of law in
fact?
Attorney General Barr. As I said, I am going to explain my
decision, and to the extent that requires any assessment of the
Mueller Report, I am going to do that the Mueller Report is
out. I am not going to----
Senator Van Hollen. Did your decision--did your decision
require you to look into the intent of the President of the
United States with respect to obstruction of justice?
Attorney General Barr. I am not going to discuss my
decision. I will lay it out after the report is out.
Senator Van Hollen. Mr. Attorney General, the thing is you
put this out there. I mean, the President went out and tweeted
the next day that he was exonerated. That was not based on
anything in the Mueller Report with respect to obstruction of
justice. That was based on your assessment. That was on March
24, and now you will not elaborate at all as to how you reached
that conclusion because I am not asking you what is in the
Mueller Report. I am asking you about your conclusion.
Let me ask you this. You said----
Attorney General Barr. Well, it was the conclusion--it was
the conclusion of a number of a people, including me, and I
obviously am the Attorney General. It was also the conclusion
of the Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein----
Senator Van Hollen. I understand. No, I have read your
letters very----
Attorney General Barr [continuing]. As well as others, and
I will discuss that decision after the report is out.
Senator Van Hollen. Did Bob Mueller support your
conclusion?
Attorney General Barr. I do not know whether Bob Mueller
supported my conclusion.
Senator Van Hollen. So in your June 2018 memo, you
indicated that a President can commit obstruction of justice in
the classic sense of sabotaging a proceeding's truth-finding
functions.
Did you see any evidence in this report about whether or
not President Trump committed what you call a classic sense of
obstruction of justice?
Attorney General Barr. I am not going to characterize or
discuss the contents of the report. The report will be made
public hopefully next week, and I will come up and testify at
that point about it.
Senator Van Hollen. But the thing about it is, Mr. General,
you put your conclusion out there, and now you refuse to talk
about any basis of your conclusion.
I am not asking you for what is in the report. I am asking
you how you reached your conclusion.
Last question. Can you assure us that the key factual
evidence relevant to charges of obstruction of justice will be
included in the public report?
Attorney General Barr. Could you just say that----
Senator Van Hollen. Can you assure us that the key factual
evidence in the Mueller Report related to charges of
obstruction of justice will be available in the public report?
Attorney General Barr. I believe it will, and that is one
of the reasons why I want to review it after, you know, when
the redaction team is done making the redactions to make sure
that there is nothing in there that would prevent that, and to
the extent--and, by the way, redactions can cut both ways.
Senator Van Hollen. My last question relates to redaction
process. My understanding from your House testimony was you are
allowing the Mueller team to make the redactions in three of
the four areas you mentioned, all of them except for
intelligence. Is that a correct understanding of your testimony
yesterday? In other words, you are leaving the discretion to
them on the three of the four criteria that you mapped out?
Attorney General Barr. I have stated what the categories
are, and the people implementing it area the Justice lawyers
with the Special Counsel's lawyers. They are implementing those
categories.
Senator Van Hollen. And you are not going to overrule this
Special Counsel's judgment with respect to any of those
categories, right?
Attorney General Barr. I have not.
Senator Van Hollen. Can you tell us you will not?
Attorney General Barr. If an issue comes up, I do not want
to prejudge it, but it is not my intention. My intention is to
allow the team to make the redactions, and the people in the
Department are making those redactions.
Senator Moran. Senator Boozman.
Senator Boozman. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Thank you very much for being here. We appreciate your
service.
OPIOIDS
We have really talked about a lot of things that are very
important. I want to talk about one that really is sweeping the
country, and it has been mentioned briefly before. And that is
the opioid epidemic, and not just that, we have an opioid
epidemic, but we also have an addiction epidemic.
In Arkansas, we are number two in prescribing. Literally,
we have got 3 million people. We have had hundreds of millions
of pills prescribed last year, and so your team, I understand,
have ranked that very high. You have kept that ranking.
But I would really like to talk about how we can come up
with some innovative new strategies in order to do that. So if
we provide you additional resources, do you have any ideas as
to anything different that we can do that we are not doing now?
We are making a dent, but there were 72,000 deaths last
year, these are statistics. Sadly, we are spending a lot of
money, but I do not know that we are having great success.
Attorney General Barr. I do think we are starting to see
some good results. I think the initial data suggests that we
finally have stopped seeing an increase in opioid overdose
deaths. It seems to be leveling out, and we hope----
Senator Boozman. Part of that is just the ability to have
the Narcan. In fact, my understanding is that drug dealers are
carrying it to keep their clients alive. So that is part of
that. I do not know what the statistic would be if we did not
have that.
Attorney General Barr. Right.
I also think we are making progress on reducing diversion
and over-prescription of the drugs, and we are locking up a lot
of healthcare providers. And we are bringing a lot of civil
actions, and I think----
Senator Boozman. And I applaud you on that.
Attorney General Barr. And we are now applying technology a
lot more to detecting places where there are suspicious
patterns of over-subscription and so forth and attacking them
very aggressively.
So on the first leg of the strategy, which is to reduce the
addicted population from illicit drugs, I think we are making
some progress.
On the illicit drugs, I think a huge part of this is to
address the problem of the traffic coming up from Mexico.
Mexico is our drug supplier, all kinds of drugs, and the
organizations in Mexico are very formidable criminal
enterprises. And we have to address that problem to stop the
flow of these really deadly drugs and increasingly deadly
drugs.
Senator Boozman. Right.
Attorney General Barr. The fentanyl mixed in with all other
kinds of drugs, so people really do not know what they are
taking. We have to address--we have to stop the flow of drugs
from Mexico or make a much bigger dent in it.
That is one of the reasons that I do think that a wall, a
barrier system across the southern border, is an important part
of that.
Senator Boozman. Another part of that is the mail, and our
postal inspectors are doing a good job. There is just not a
whole lot of them, and in the past--it is much better now, but
in the past, the interoperability has not been there. That is
much better now than it used to be.
But I wish you would look into that in the sense that you
mentioned the southern border, and I agree with you totally.
The mail from China is a huge problem.
Attorney General Barr. Right.
Senator Boozman. And then also getting these shipments and
then distributing them throughout the rest of the Country from
someplace here is a huge problem.
Attorney General Barr. Right.
Well, the FBI has a great tool, what we call J-CODE, which
is starting to get some big successes on Internet trafficking
of drugs, and I think attacking both the dark net and the
regular Internet and these online--and policing the mails is a
very important part of it, and we are now applying the
technology to get a lot more progress on these online dealers.
On the mail front, there are some sensing technologies that
are coming along that are very promising in terms of being able
to intercept them.
DRUG COURTS
Senator Boozman. And then, finally, one of the tools that
we have that I think is one of the most effective are the drug
courts. The VA is doing that now. Others are doing that. Having
the ability to make somebody stay clean, have a job so they can
support their families--most of them do--really is a great
asset. So I would hope that you would support that. That is the
way that we can I think really also make a dent.
Attorney General Barr. Yes. I very much support the drug
courts, the veterans courts, and there is $75 million in our
budget for those. So we will continue to support that.
Senator Boozman. Good. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Senator Moran. You are welcome.
In approximately 15 minutes, we have a vote, a set of votes
of three. Senator Coons is next, followed by Senator Graham,
then Schatz, then Senator Feinstein.
We will, as I said earlier, attempt to--we will conclude
shortly after the vote is called.
Senator Coons.
Senator Coons. Thank you, Chairman Moran.
Thank you, Attorney General Barr, for your service and for
being here, and for Mr. Lofthus, I have many questions about
the budget. But I am going to first turn to some questions that
I think are more urgent and concerning about the Special
Counsel's report.
SPECIAL COUNSEL MUELLER'S INVESTIGATION
The primary purpose of the Special Counsel's investigation
was both to thoroughly investigate issues around the 2016
election but also to provide a clear and objective conclusion
in a report to the American people.
I am concerned that over the last 3 weeks, your actions
have created some confusion and distrust around the process and
look forward to the imminent release of as much of that report
as you can to the American people and to Congress.
You stated that the redacted portions of the Special
Counsel's report will be color-coded and accompanied by
explanatory notes to describe the basis for redactions. Will
those notes merely indicate which of the four categories was
applied or provide some information to Congress about the
specific justification for redactions?
You mentioned you envision a situation where Congress,
under the appropriate safeguards, could verify the redaction
categories were not abused. Can you tell me something about the
safeguards you have in mind?
Attorney General Barr. You know, I do not know how detailed
the descriptions will be. Some of them may just be generic, but
some of them may be able to provide additional information.
So, for example, if there is a gag order in a case that
says--apart from whatever we feel about impinging on the case,
there is a gag order that would be implicated by release. I
expect that that will be put in.
Senator Coons. And are those safeguards likely to be worked
out with the Chair and Ranking of Judiciary----
Attorney General Barr. Right.
Senator Coons [continuing]. Who also just happen to----
Attorney General Barr. In terms of the safeguards--so, for
example, an easy one in my view is the classified information.
I would just want to make sure there were adequate safeguards
and shared with a limited number of people, that kind of thing,
the thing we would normally do in this situation.
Senator Coons. I was struck that the District Court of the
District of Columbia reported recently the grand jury convened
by Mueller has not been discharged and is continuing its
investigation.
Did anyone pressure the Special Counsel to conclude his
investigation and submit his report before it was complete?
Attorney General Barr. I did not.
Senator Coons. Did anyone else to your knowledge?
Attorney General Barr. Not that I am aware of.
Senator Coons. There are press accounts that members of the
Special Counsel's team, his investigators, prepared summaries
for public release of sections of the report. Why did you
summarize the principal conclusions reached by the Special
Counsel and the results of investigation rather than releasing
some of these prepared-for-public-release summaries?
Attorney General Barr. So, actually, Deputy Attorney
General Rosenstein and I were expecting a report that would
make it very easy for us to determine what had to be taken out
and what was not, and that is not how the report came to us.
So I immediately recognized that there was going to be some
significant lag time between our receipt of the report and when
we could actually get it out and decided that--none of it was
releasable as I received it because none of it had been vetted
for Rule 6(e) material, but every page on it had a warning that
it could contain 6(e) material.
So as of----
Senator Coons. So every page had a warning, and you were
certain that the Mueller team had not vetted it?
Attorney General Barr. It had not been vetted.
Senator Coons. There were not summaries.
Let me get to two other questions, if I could. Forgive me
since----
Attorney General Barr. So I am just saying that on--I felt
it was important to just advise the Country as to what the
bottom-line conclusions were. I was not interested actually,
even if I had summaries available, which I did not on Sunday,
that were vetted, I would not have put out summaries because I
think summaries, no matter who is preparing them, are going to
be subject to criticism.
What people have to remember, that generally the Department
of Justice does come out with binary conclusions, and so just
stating the bottom line on each of those I think was entirely
appropriate.
Senator Coons. Who, if anyone, outside the Justice
Department, has seen portions or all of the Special Counsel's
report? Has anyone in the White House seen any of the report?
Attorney General Barr. You know, I am not going to--as I
say, I am landing the plane right now, and I have been willing
to discuss my letters and the process going forward, but the
report is going to be out next week. And I am just not going to
get into the details of the process until the plane is on the
ground.
Senator Coons. At what point will you allow Congress to
know whether or not the White House was given the full report,
briefed on the report, shared sections of the report?
Attorney General Barr. Once I go up to----
Senator Coons. It is striking the President claimed
complete and total exoneration if he did not either see the
report or was briefed on the report.
Attorney General Barr. As I said, once the report is out, I
am happy to discuss the process.
Senator Coons. I very much look forward to that.
My last question. Given your unsolicited June 8 letter to
the Justice Department regarding obstruction of justice, did
you ever consider recusing yourself from making a conclusion
about whether a charge of obstruction of justice should have
been made?
Attorney General Barr. Well, I consulted with the career
ethics officials at the Department.
Senator Coons. And they concluded that your memo on that
topic did not require your recusal?
Attorney General Barr. That is correct.
Senator Coons. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Senator Moran. You are welcome.
Chairman Graham, the Attorney General has been very
faithful to his insistence that he not disclose anything of
significance until he is in front of your committee.
Senator Graham. Great. But you cannot possibly be surprised
that President Trump would claim exoneration without having
read anything.
[Laughter.]
Senator Graham. So, anyway, I hate to talk about
appropriations in Appropriations Committee, but I will.
Senator Moran. We will welcome that.
Senator Graham. Okay.
If sequestration goes back into effect--and it is due to do
that--how would it affect the FBI and your ability to defend
the Nation?
Attorney General Barr. Could I turn that over to my trusty
sidekick here?
Senator Graham. Yes. Or did you pick a winning lottery
ticket to be here with him?
Attorney General Barr. Throw the hard ones.
Senator Graham. Yes.
SEQUESTRATION
Mr. Lofthus. I can tell you the last time we had full
sequestration in 2013, the Department had $1.3 billion at risk.
People at the FBI, the rest of our law enforcement agencies,
the Bureau of Prisons, all those agencies had their funding
impacted, their staffing impacted. People were at risk for
furlough. We had to move several hundred million dollars from
other accounts into the Department, into our S&E accounts to
keep our people working. Sequestration had a tremendous,
tremendous impact on the Department of Justice, took tremendous
work to avoid the detrimental effects of sequestration the last
time----
Senator Graham. Do you believe that if we go back down that
road, it would make us less safe?
Mr. Lofthus. I believe it would curtail the safety
operations of the Department of Justice and its national
security operations.
Senator Graham. Okay. Thank you.
Mr. Attorney General, I am sure you share that assessment?
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
SPECIAL COUNSEL MUELLER'S INVESTIGATION
Senator Graham. Okay. As to what you are going to do on May
1, we will save that mostly for May 1, but I am intrigued by
the idea of this working group or some group looking at the
other side of the ledger.
Do you agree with me that every American should be
concerned as to whether or not a warrant was obtained against
an American citizen with unverified information?
Attorney General Barr. Absolutely. I think the Fourth
Amendment is one of our most cherished civil liberties.
Senator Graham. So you think that is an appropriate thing
to look at, and you will look at it?
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Graham. Okay. Do you share my concern that if you
are going to open up a counterintelligence investigation
against a presidential candidate that you have to have a very
good reason?
Attorney General Barr. Yes, absolutely.
Senator Graham. And a counterintelligence investigation is
designed to protect the target of foreign influence; is that
correct?
Attorney General Barr. That is correct.
Senator Graham. It is not a prosecutorial function, is it?
Attorney General Barr. No, unless espionage or some
violation of espionage law develops.
Senator Graham. So would it be odd that the candidate was
never really briefed by the Department of Justice that your
campaign may be targeted by a foreign entity?
Attorney General Barr. That is one of the questions I have
I feel normally the campaign would have been advised of this.
Senator Graham. And can you think of a good reason right
now why they would not have been?
Attorney General Barr. I am interested in getting that
answer. They had two former U.S. Attorneys in Chris Christie
and Rudy Giuliani involved in the campaign, and I do not
understand why the campaign was not advised.
Senator Graham. Apparently, when Senator Feinstein had a
person on her staff that was supposedly connected to the
Chinese government, she was briefed. Is that the normal way you
do things with a counterintelligence investigation?
Attorney General Barr. I think----
Senator Graham. Well, she was briefed about a staff member
that they thought might be connected to the Chinese government,
and she took action and fired the guy. Is that sort of what you
are supposed to be doing?
Attorney General Barr. That is what I would--if I were
Attorney General and that situation came up, I would say,
``Yes. Brief the target of the foreign espionage activity.''
Senator Graham. Okay. So you are pledging to this
subcommittee and I guess to the country as a whole as to find
out what happened with the warrant application, find out about
the counterintelligence investigation to make sure that the law
was followed, and if there was any abuse of the law, to report
it to the Congress and the public. Is that accurate?
Attorney General Barr. That is accurate. I just want to
satisfy myself that there was no abuse of law enforcement or
intelligence powers.
Senator Graham. I am glad you are doing that.
When it comes to Mr. Mueller, are you talking to him about
the 6(e) material?
Attorney General Barr. I have not personally talked to him
about the Rule 6(e), but his people are working on the 6(e)
material.
Senator Graham. So there is a collaboration between your
people and Mueller people about what to take out and what to
leave in on the grand jury side?
Attorney General Barr. Yes. As it was described to me,
people are sitting at the same table.
Senator Graham. When it comes to ongoing criminal
investigations, you are making sure that prosecutors, they have
a say about what is released because it may jeopardize their
cases?
Attorney General Barr. That is right, the people involved
in those cases.
Senator Graham. And when it comes to classified
information, you are talking to the intelligence community----
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Graham [continuing]. To make sure they are okay?
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Graham. Thank you very much.
Senator Moran. Senator Schatz.
Senator Schatz. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Thank you, Attorney General, for being here.
I want to give you a chance to rephrase something you said
because I think when the Attorney General of the United States
uses the word ``spying,'' it is rather provocative and, in my
view, unnecessarily inflammatory.
I know what you are getting at because you have explained
yourself in terms of answering Senator Graham's questions and
the questions of others.
Do you want to rephrase what you are doing? Because I think
the word ``spying'' could cause everybody in the cable news
ecosystem to freak out, and I think it is necessary for you to
be precise with your language here. You normally are, and I
want to give you a chance to be especially precise here.
Attorney General Barr. I am not sure of all the
connotations of that word that you are referring to, but
unauthorized surveillance, I want to make sure there was no
unauthorized surveillance.
Senator Schatz. Okay. Thank you.
Attorney General Barr. Is that more appropriate in your
mind?
Senator Schatz. This is your call. I really did want to
give you a chance to say it how you wanted to say it and make
sure that you did not misspeak because you have talked for a
long time. You had yesterday, and I want to make sure that
you----
Attorney General Barr. I appreciate that.
Senator Schatz [continuing]. Use the words that you want to
use.
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Schatz. Okay. On the Mueller summaries, on the
Mueller team summaries within the report, I get that on every
page, there was a sort of admonition that this may contain 6(e)
material. The question I have relates to your desire to make
sure that the whole thing is intelligible. Are these reports
going to be--excuse me. Are these summaries when the report is
released going to be intelligible? I assume there may be some
redactions. There may be none. But the basic question I think
for the public is, Are we going to get the gist of this, or is
it going to be on January of 2015 and then you have to flip 15
pages to find the next text?
Attorney General Barr. You will get more than the gist.
Senator Schatz. Thank you.
COLE MEMORANDUM
I want to ask you about the Cole Memorandum. In your
confirmation hearing, you said, ``I am not going to go after
companies that have relied on the Cole Memorandum.'' Are you
planning on restoring it? Are you planning on establishing your
new guidance?
I heard what you said about marijuana generally, but those
are public policy questions. Assuming we cannot come to an
agreement on a new statutory framework, what is the plan for
the Department of Justice?
Attorney General Barr. I am going to have to make some
difficult choices.
Senator Schatz. Do you care to elaborate?
Attorney General Barr. Well, for example, reliance suggests
people who have already taken action based on the Cole
Memorandum.
I mean, one open question in my mind is if States continue
to pass these laws, are we going to continue to forebear on
those new States? I would like to see Congress address this
issue.
Senator Schatz. Is there any internal guidance regarding
these sort of difficult questions?
Attorney General Barr. None that I have given.
Senator Schatz. So the Department of Justice is operating
without guidance?
Attorney General Barr. The Department of Justice is
operating under my general guidance that I am accepting the
Cole Memorandum for now, but I have generally left it up to the
U.S. Attorneys in each State to determine what the best
approach is in that State.
Senator Schatz. Okay.
Attorney General Barr. I have not heard any complaints from
the States that have legalized marijuana.
Senator Schatz. A year ago, Attorney General Sessions said
we are moving forward, and we will add fairly soon, additional
suppliers of marijuana under the Controlled Substances Act. I
have sent two follow-up letters. Where are we on this?
Attorney General Barr. I have been pushing very hard over
the last few weeks to get that process under way, and I think
we are going to move forward on it. I think it is very
important to get those additional suppliers.
Senator Schatz. Can you assure me that I am not going to be
here a year later asking the same question?
Attorney General Barr. Yes.
Senator Schatz. Thank you.
AFFORDABLE CARE ACT (ACA)
On defending the ACA, how often has the Department of
Justice declined to defend a Federal statute?
Attorney General Barr. It has happened--I cannot give you a
number.
Senator Schatz. Is it fair to say it is infrequent?
Attorney General Barr. It is infrequent, but it happens,
and it happens under different kinds of--you know, the Obama
administration refused to defend----
Senator Schatz. Sure. And I think that was the only one,
and I think that that is sort of telling that as policy, you
try to make these choices as infrequently as possible.
Attorney General Barr. Correct.
Senator Schatz. And under the Obama administration, they
refused to defend the Defense of Marriage Act, and under the
Trump administration, you are refusing to defend the Affordable
Care Act.
So it sort of has to rise to a level of political and
public policy importance that supersedes the judgment of a lot
of career attorneys. Would you agree with that?
Attorney General Barr. Well, I think I am not sure whether
it is a question of career attorneys or non-career attorneys. I
mean, there frequently are disputes among lawyers within an
administration, whether they be career or non-career.
Senator Schatz. Thank you.
Attorney General Barr. Okay.
Senator Moran. Senator Feinstein.
Senator Feinstein. If I may, Mr. Chairman. On Senator
Schatz's question of you, Mr. Attorney General, I am really
surprised by the answer because the Supreme Court did uphold
the law, the ACA, and now the Attorney General is saying we
will not defend it, regardless.
It seems to me that that is as problem. That if something
is duly passed and upheld as legal that the Attorney General
has a duty to defend it.
Attorney General Barr. Well, the law was originally upheld
because the mandate was upheld as a tax, and Chief Justice
Roberts' opinion said that it can be upheld as a tax even
though it could not otherwise be upheld.
But for finding it a tax, you would have had five votes
against it.
Senator Feinstein. But that----
Attorney General Barr. Once the penalty was removed, the
financial penalty was removed, that provision could no longer
be justified as a tax, which means that it would have to fall.
So the mandate fell. The mandate in my opinion--I do not think
it is even a close question. The mandate was unconstitutional
because it can no longer be upheld as a tax.
Then the question becomes if the mandate falls, even though
there was no penalty attached to it, what is its impact on the
rest of the statute? Four of the justices in the NFIB felt that
the whole statute had to fall. So, as I said before you
arrived, Senator, at the end of the day, I felt that this was a
defensible legal position to take.
Senator Feinstein. In my experience, which I guess I have
been here 26 years, I have never seen this before that a
decision like this would be made by one individual on the basis
of what has been a huge decision legislatively and signed by a
President based on--I am not sure quite what, despite what you
said, so----
Attorney General Barr. Who was the one individual? Me?
Senator Feinstein. No, no.
Attorney General Barr. Oh, okay.
Senator Feinstein. No, you misunderstood what I said.
Attorney General Barr. Okay.
Senator Feinstein. But it is not important.
You are saying despite the fact that the Supreme Court of
the United States upheld what has been a major law duly passed,
duly signed by the President, that you are just not going to
defend it?
Attorney General Barr. That does happen. It happens
occasionally in our system.
I think the principle over at the Department of Justice is
that our default position, our preference is to defend
statutes, even if we do not agree with the statutes and even if
we think the argument is a weak argument.
For example, last time I was in the Justice Department, I
thought the flag statute was unconstitutional, but we defend it
in the no burning of the flag. We defended it. We lost because
the Justice Department was correct on that.
Senator Feinstein. But why would not you defend this?
Attorney General Barr. Because occasionally the
administration determines that another position should be
taken.
Senator Feinstein. Is this determined by the White House?
Attorney General Barr. It is determined by the process
within the executive branch. There are a number of agencies.
There are a number of different players even in the White House
that get involved in these things.
Senator Feinstein. Well, I assume you would not take this
position unless this is what the President wanted----
Attorney General Barr. Well, that would be a safe
assumption.
Senator Feinstein [continuing]. Because this is as mega
law. You know, it affects preexisting conditions. It affects
everybody in the United States. It is not--it went through a
great deal of hearing and testimony and amendment passage.
Attorney General Barr. Yes. It was a very controversial
law.
Senator Feinstein. Exactly. But it is a big law.
Attorney General Barr. Right.
Senator Feinstein. And it has been operational for a period
of time, and people depend on it, millions of people, for their
healthcare.
Attorney General Barr. Okay.
Senator Feinstein. And so, all of a sudden, along comes--
and this is just my frame of way of saying it--somebody and,
oh, I am going to take this whole thing on and----
Attorney General Barr. Well, there were 20, I think, or
more States that were challenging it. There was a lot of
opposition to it. A lot of States have weighed in, and I think
the administration is on the side of those States.
As I said yesterday, I think people should sort of take a
deep breath. If this is such a whacky position that the
administration is taking, then there is nothing to fear, right?
Senator Feinstein. Well----
Attorney General Barr. Then the law will be upheld.
Senator Feinstein. In 26 years, I have never seen this kind
of thing, and I----
Attorney General Barr. Well, Defense of Marriage Act
(DOMA), I mean, we mentioned that before. I know it happens
rarely in each administration, but I would be surprised if not
any--you know, most administrations have from time to time
declined----
Senator Feinstein. Well, maybe--I do not want to take the
time. Maybe we can discuss this because this struck me like
lightning that one person decided--I assume the President wants
you to--that made this decision, and everything that was done
by way of proper legislative action has been taken and
signature of a President. I just do not ever recall anything
like this happening in the past quarter of a century.
Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Senator Moran. Thank you, Senator Feinstein.
Attorney General, we are about to conclude. I have a
follow-up question, so does Senator Shaheen. Then we will wrap
up.

[The following questions were not asked at the hearing, but
were submitted to the Department for response subsequent to the
hearing:]
Questions Submitted to Hon. William P. Barr
Questions Submitted by Senator Jerry Moran
contraband phones in prisons
Question 1. I was pleased to see a pilot program included in the
request to attempt to solve the issue of contraband cellphones in the
Federal Prison System. Contraband cellphones pose a myriad of threats,
both inside and outside of Bureau of Prison (BOP) facilities. Will you
please provide more detail as to what this program will do if funds are
provided?
Answer. The $4.625 million requested for fiscal year 2020 to
implement cell phone detection and mitigation technology will allow BOP
to conduct a proof-of-concept of a Managed Access Solution (MAS) and/or
Micro-Jamming Solution (MJS) at two facilities and perform valuable
mobile MAS assessments. MAS and MJS are the two viable wireless
interdiction technologies that are technically feasible and deployable
today. MAS is deployed by a vendor under a sub-license from a wireless
carrier, captures all cellular signals within the geo-spatial confines
of a prison and disables unauthorized cellular signals from contraband
devices. In contrast, MJS jams all cellular signals within the geo-
spatial confines of a prison. The objective is to render cellular
communication within the geospatial area useless. The pilot would run
for 1 year. BOP expects to gauge the efficacy of both technologies and
determine their cost-effectiveness. Both pilots are necessary to assess
the technologies' ability to address the compelling public safety issue
of contraband cell phones. This testing is mission critical as these
devices are used by inmates and co-conspirators to conduct illicit
criminal activity, foment escape, facilitate the introduction of
dangerous contraband, and threaten staff, other inmates and members of
the public.
In April, BOP conducted a pilot test of MJS at the Broad River
Correctional Institution in Columbia, S.C. The test--the first
collaboration of this kind in a State corrections facility--was
conducted to determine if micro-jamming could prevent wireless
communication by inmates using contraband cellphones in a housing unit.
The test results are promising, showing that MJS technology could be
effective in preventing the use of contraband cellphones in prisons.
This test followed two earlier tests at a Federal corrections facility
in Cumberland, Md., one of which included a micro-jamming test showing
that the technology rendered cellular signals inoperable inside a
single cell.
Typical quotes received from MAS or MJS solution providers to
install a system with only cellular wireless interdiction usually
exceed $1 million per facility. The infrastructure costs (network,
fiber optic cabling, switches, sensors, etc.) are comparable for MAS or
MJS applications. While no two sites are exactly the same, there are
three general contexts for implementation: (1) an institution in a
rural location, (2) an institution in a light urban area, and finally,
(3) an institution in a metropolitan location. Each context has its own
unique set of challenges and opportunities.
By grouping sites in this manner, and using MAS or MJS as the
technology solution, BOP can provide a gross estimate of the required
pre-deployment efforts to modify the facility infrastructure, deploy
system electronics, and sustain the capability with a focus on
efficacy, affordability, and maintainability. The current estimated
cost to implement a viable cellphone detection and mitigation
technology in these three contexts ranges are as follows:
--Rural Sites Surveys and Deployments $795,000-$1,795,000
--Light Urban Sites Surveys and Deployments $1,050,000-$2,050,000
--Metropolitan Sites Surveys and Deployments $2,080,000-$3,080,000
The proposed tests would occur in a rural and light urban setting.
Thus, the BOP is requesting $2 million for a MAS pilot and $2 million
for a MJS pilot.
The BOP also requests 25 mobile MAS assessments for $625,000.
Mobile MAS assessments are used by the agency to dynamically target
correctional facilities that have made significant contraband cellphone
seizures. Such assessments cost $25,000 per 2-day assessment. This
technology is portable and can be relocated as needed; it is a valuable
and flexible measure to react quickly to an identified or trending
threat without a requirement to install infrastructure. In calendar
year 2019, we are conducting 10 mobile MAS assessments using existing
internal funds targeting institutions with significant numbers of
seized cell phones, like FCI Fort Dix. BOP is collaborating with DOJ on
a new seizure warrant process to disable contraband cell phones
identified within the geo-spatial confines of a Federal prison using
data derived from a mobile MAS assessment.
Any MAS or MJS solution should augment existing sound correctional
procedures and physical security technologies already in operational
daily use.
drones/unmanned aircraft systems (uas) and counter uas measures
Question 2. Technology is ever changing and advancing, which
unfortunately means threats are also often evolving. There have been
reports of drone use over and around prisons. What is BOP doing to
prevent outside drones from entering the airspace above its facilities,
and what are the counter drone or counter unmanned aircraft system
(UAS) resource needs for BOP? Additionally, are there Drone or UAS
needs to monitor and secure BOP facilities?
Answer. The Bureau of Prisons (Bureau) is fully committed to
addressing the threat posed by drones to the safety and security of its
facilities. The Preventing Emerging Threats Act of 2018 included in the
FAA Reauthorization Act signed into law in October 2018 provides the
Department and its components, including the Bureau, the legal
authority to detect and disrupt unmanned aircraft systems deemed to be
a ``credible threat'' to certain covered facilities and assets,
including Bureau institutions at high risk from the drone threat,
notwithstanding laws that could otherwise prohibit or limit such
activities. The Bureau played a leading role in securing this
authority, completed numerous briefings on the threat, and potential
mitigation measures, to Congressional Members and staff in 2017 and
2018. The Department is working to implement the new authorities and is
developing guidance for its law enforcement components to deploy
counter-UAS systems consistent with the law.
In the interim, the Department is working closely with the FAA and
with the Bureau to protect institutions. The Bureau has made great
strides in laying the groundwork for counter-UAS protection at its
facilities. Currently, 108 of 122 BOP sites are covered by a Temporary
Flight Restriction (TFR) or pending TFR (Notice to Airmen, or NOTAM,
for last 55 sites effective 11/7/2019). While TFRs do not prevent
illegal overflights, they establish both fair warning for careless and
clueless operators, and set up potential criminal sanctions for
criminal ones. This is the first step to preventing outside drones from
entering the airspace above its facilities. Next, consistent with the
Preventing Emerging Threats Act, and after completing testing and
evaluation of various c-UAS systems in fiscal year 2020, the Bureau
aims to deploy protective systems at multiple high security United
States Penitentiaries in fiscal year 2021. The Department will continue
to provide semi-annual briefings to relevant Congressional committees
about counter-UAS activities.
Question 3. I understand there are several DOJ Working Groups
regarding drones and counter drone measures. How many groups are there
and what is each group's focus? Which components are involved in these
working groups?
Answer. The Department takes both the threat and promise of
Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS) seriously and has dedicated significant
resources to ensure effective operational and policy outcomes in this
area. In doing so, the Department confronts a wide range of legal,
policy, and operational issues, which span three primary categories:
(1) countering UAS threats pursuant to new statutory authority; (2)
contributing to interagency discussions on UAS policy and coordinating
the Department's own use of UAS in the National Airspace System (NAS);
and (3) criminal enforcement activities.
The Department's Office of Legal Policy (OLP) chairs a Department-
wide UAS Working Group, which includes representatives from numerous
Department components including: the Federal Bureau of Investigation,
the Drug Enforcement Administration, the United States Marshals
Service, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives, the
Bureau of Prisons, the Office of the Deputy Attorney General, the
Office of Legal Policy, the National Security Division, the Criminal
Division, the Executive Office for United States Attorneys, the Office
of Justice Programs, the Office of Community Oriented Policing, the
Office of Privacy and Civil Liberties, the Office of the Chief
Information Officer, and the Office of Legislative Affairs. The Working
Group coordinates the Department's efforts related to UAS under the
supervision of the Office of the Deputy Attorney General.
In conjunction with the National Security Division, OLP is
overseeing the process of drafting and implementing Department-wide
Guidance on the use of counter-UAS equipment to protect certain key
sites, such as Federal prisons and courthouses, and events, such as the
Super Bowl and the World Series. The Guidance is required by the
recently enacted Preventing Emerging Threats Act of 2018, which grants
DOJ the authority to mitigate credible UAS threats. In February 2019,
the Department used the authority for the first time to protect Super
Bowl LIII from potential drone threats. That operation proved very
successful, leading to the detection and seizure of dozens of drones
that violated protected airspace around the stadium. In October 2019,
the Department again used the authority to protect the World Series
from potential drone threats in Houston and Washington, D.C. The
Department also used the authority to protect the New York City
Marathon.
To further support its counter-UAS efforts, the Department also
recently formed a Counter-UAS Operational Test and Evaluation Committee
(COTEC), which evaluates the most promising counter-UAS technologies
for use by Department components. The COTEC performs that function in
close coordination with the Departments of Defense and Homeland
Security. Each of the Department's law enforcement components are
represented on the Committee.
Additionally, the UAS Working Group is focused on supporting FAA in
developing policies on UAS and coordinating the Department's
affirmative use of drones, ensuring that such use advances the
Department's missions, promotes public safety, and protects privacy and
civil liberties.
Finally, the Executive Office of United States Attorneys (EOUSA)
coordinates the Department's efforts to train and educate prosecutors
and investigators across the country and across agencies on criminal
and civil enforcement tools available to respond to UAS incidents, such
as the use of drones to smuggle contraband into Federal prisons, to
violate restricted airspace or to interfere with firefighting
operations. Recent efforts by law enforcement have included, for
example, the investigation and prosecution of a Georgia man who
illegally operated a UAS with the intent to deliver marijuana into the
Autry State Prison in Pelham, Georgia. The prosecution ultimately
resulted in the defendant's guilty plea in the Middle District of
Georgia to the charge of Operating an Aircraft Eligible for
Registration Knowing that the Aircraft is Not Registered to Facilitate
a Controlled Substance Offense. On October 31, 2019, the defendant was
sentenced to 48 months in prison, followed by 3 years of supervised
release.
Question 4. Are there policies and procedures in place for DOJ
components and grantees regarding the purchase of UAS or Counter UAS
systems? Do these policies and procedures address foreign made UAS or
Counter UAS systems?
Answer. First, DOJ Policy Order 0904: Cybersecurity Program
requires that IT acquisitions follow supply chain risk management
(SCRM) procedures. That policy applies to DOJ components, but not
grantees. In fiscal year 2019, DOJ's Justice Management Division issued
a Department-wide policy clarifying that Unmanned Aircraft Systems
(UAS) and counter-UAS systems are generally IT systems and, as such,
are subject to the supply chain risk management process. In general,
those procedures generally require a review of the risks associated
with UAS or counter-UAS systems, and consideration of any appropriate
mitigation measures.
Second, Department Memorandum 14-03 provides guidance to DOJ
components on the acquisition of high or moderate-impact IT systems.
Third, DOJ Procurement Guidance Document (PGD) 16-02 governs the IT
Acquisition Review Board process. Together, these policies ensure that
DOJ components: maintain proper technical security controls and
managerial oversight processes regarding the purchase of UAS or
counter-UAS systems; identify any threats posed by foreign made IT
systems and components; and implement appropriate risk mitigation plans
to mitigate such threats. In order to ensure the security of systems
purchased by grantees through the DOJ Office of Justice Programs (OJP)
grants process, the Justice Assistance Grant (JAG) program specifically
prohibits the use of grant funds for the purchase of Unmanned Aerial
Vehicles (UAV) and UAS items (among other items specifically prohibited
under the statute (34 U.S.C. Sec. Sec. 10151-10158)) unless the Bureau
of Justice Assistance ``Director certifies that extraordinary and
exigent circumstances exist, making them essential to the maintenance
of public safety and good order.'' To request that such a certification
be made, the grant recipient must submit a request for a Grant
Adjustment Notice along with a letter from the authorized
representative of the grant recipient that includes a detailed
justification for the request.
eoir's resource needs
Question 5. In fiscal year 2019, Congress appropriated the
President's request for the Executive Office of Immigration Review,
EOIR. However, on March 6, 2019, EOIR Director James McHenry, emailed
all EOIR employees, stating EOIR's fiscal year 2019 funding level was
insufficient and left EOIR unable to fulfill all of its current
operational needs. What resource shortfalls, if any, is EOIR
experiencing? If there are shortfalls, why were these not communicated
to Congress?
Answer. Although I was not with the Department at the time, it is
my understanding that prior to January 2019, the House of
Representatives was recommending $630 million in funding for the
Executive Office for Immigration Review (EOIR) in fiscal year 2019,
which was roughly $66 million more than the Department's request. Thus,
there was not necessarily a basis to seek additional funding from
Congress, as the House had already recommended funding above the
Department's request. Due to the shutdown and the timing of the
appropriations process, EOIR did not have an effective opportunity to
raise concerns or address recent interpreter cost projections prior to
the enactment of the fiscal year 2019 appropriations. The Department's
fiscal year 2020 request includes increases for EOIR that meet its
operational needs. The Department remains appreciative of Congress's
continued support of EOIR, and is committed to ensuring sufficient
resources are dedicated to processing immigration court cases in a
timely and efficient manner consistent with due process.
Question 6. EOIR's interpreter contract seems to be the root cause
of concern for Director McHenry's email. It is my understanding that
the original interpreter contract cost $20 million, but then ballooned
to over $110 million, and has now receded to $70 million. Why did the
cost of this contract fluctuate so dramatically? What efforts is the
Department making to ensure EOIR is using its resources responsibly and
that poor contractor performance is not being rewarded?
Answer. Although I was not with the Department when the issues with
the cost of in-person interpretation services first manifested, my
understanding is that the cost of EOIR in-person interpretation has
risen for two principal reasons: an increase in the terms of the
contract itself following a renegotiation and an increase in the need
for interpreter services due to increases in the number of immigration
judges and the number of hearings being held in immigration court.
First, the market rate for interpreters has increased significantly
since the current interpreter contract was let in 2015. This increase
in market rates for interpreters is primarily due to competition for
interpreters at the local, State, and Federal levels, as well as the
private sector. At the time the contract was let in 2015, the
contractor's rates appeared viable. Increased market demand for
interpreters soon caused those rates to become below-market, and the
contractor had difficulty recruiting qualified interpreters which led
to higher no-show rates and, in turn, assessments of liquidated damages
against the contractor. Accordingly, in 2016, the contractor requested
a renegotiation of terms, including higher rates for their contract
interpreters. The Department and the contractor concluded the
renegotiated contract in 2017, which included increased rates for
interpretation and a higher minimum cost for an in-person interpreter.
The Department completed a thorough analysis of the contract to ensure
that the pricing and terms are consistent with current industry
standards and norms.
Second, the number of immigration judges and the number of
immigration court hearings have increased significantly since 2015,
which has further increased the need for interpreters. EOIR has added a
net of 188 immigration judges since September 2015 when the current
contract went into effect, and the number of hearings has nearly
doubled, from 964,916 in fiscal year 2015 to nearly 1.9 million in
fiscal year 2019. As a result, the number of interpreter orders has
also essentially doubled, from 62,835 in fiscal year 2015 to 125,015 in
fiscal year 2019. Further, the percentage of hearings in English has
declined by approximately 7 percent over that same time period, and the
overall number of cases requiring a non-Spanish contract interpreter,
which is more expensive than a Spanish contract interpreter, has
increased.
These factors combined have led to an increase in the cost of
interpretation services from approximately $14,000,000 in fiscal year
2015 to over $75,000,000 in fiscal year 2019. These costs are expected
to increase further due to the continued influx of illegal immigration,
as the Department of Homeland Security filed the highest number of new
cases with the immigration courts in history: 443,729 in fiscal year
2019.
To address these increases, the Department has re-calculated the
baseline cost for an immigration judge (IJ) team in EOIR's request so
that the current IJ team cost includes the increased interpretation
costs. The Department is also examining other methods to manage
interpreter costs such as adding more full-time Federal employee
interpreters.
Question 7. In fiscal year 2019 Congress provided the President's
request of $25 million to develop an Electronic Case Monitoring System
(ECAS). Congress also included Report Language directing EOIR to
develop a plan to integrate the existing case backlog into this new
ECAS system and submit a report to the Committee within 30 days of
enactment regarding this plan. To date, the Committee has not received
this report. What is the Department's plan to incorporate existing
cases into this new system so that these cases might also receive
electronic efficiency benefits? When can Congress expect EOIR's ECAS
system to be fully operational?
Answer. Although the delay in enacting the fiscal year 2019
appropriation necessarily delayed the ordering of certain IT equipment
required to begin the nationwide rollout of EOIR's electronic case
filing system (ECAS), EOIR expects to begin that rollout in late 2019.
The rollout is expected to proceed in phases over the next two to 3
years. Full operational capability for the ECAS system will depend, in
some part, on the timing and funding level allocated to EOIR through
the fiscal year 2020 appropriation process and potentially future
appropriation processes. EOIR's fiscal year 2020 request includes
$10.9M for activities associated with the second year of ECAS
programming, purchasing, rollout and maintenance; a reduction from the
$25 million initially appropriated in fiscal year 2019. This funding is
necessary to provide for the teams of trainers and the remaining
equipment necessary to roll out the ECAS program to the immigration
courts. Integrating all current pending cases into ECAS may not be
logistically feasible because of the time necessary to scan the files
of all pending cases and the phased nature of ECAS implementation.
Moreover, EOIR would still need to maintain the paper file for pending
cases, essentially requiring EOIR to maintain two sets of records.
Further, many cases are close to completion, and there would be no
benefit scanning cases that are nearly completed.
After December 31, 2022, the Federal Records Centers (FRCs) will no
longer accept transfers of records in paper format. As a result, the
Department has made it a priority for its agencies to accession as many
paper files as possible to the FRCs prior to the deadline. Any files
not sent prior to that deadline will need to be digitized or maintained
locally. The Department is still developing its plan for addressing
those records, and EOIR cannot predict at this time which current cases
will still be pending as of December 31, 2022. Nevertheless, the
Department expects that a funding request associated with digitizing/
scanning files due to the FRC deadline will be forthcoming in future
budget requests, and that digitization may potentially allow those
cases to be integrated into ECAS as well.
EOIR has submitted a report regarding ECAS each month since March
2019. It is included at the end of the monthly report transmitted by
JMD titled ``Fiscal Year 2019 Personnel, Hiring, and Caseload Report.''
EOIR submitted additional information directly addressing these
questions with the July 2019 monthly report.
Question 8. What is the total cost associated with integrating the
existing backlog into ECAS?
Answer. The expenses associated with integrating existing cases
into ECAS would include: (1) scanning all current cases that are not
electronic and that are not completed by the date ECAS is implemented
at a particular court, (2) scanning all future cases filed at a court
until the date that ECAS is implemented at that court, (3) scanning all
reopened or remanded cases and (4) the opportunity costs and
miscellaneous costs associated with reallocating employee work to this
project, especially for cases that will be completed in the near
future. EOIR cannot presently estimate any of these costs with
precision because it cannot predict when cases will be completed, how
many and when new cases will be filed in the future, or which cases
will be reopened or remanded in the future. Nevertheless, using the
pending caseload as a rough proxy and a baseline for the first cost,
EOIR estimates that it would cost $49,500,000 and take 10 years to scan
the approximately 990,000 current pending cases, based on an estimation
of scanning 100,000 files per year at a rate of $50 per file with each
file taking 1 hour to scan.
Question 9. It is my understanding that, currently, when an
individual moves, or for any other reason, appears in front of
different immigration court dockets, their paper file is mailed or
shipped to the new court. What are these mailing/shipping costs for the
Department?
Answer. Over fiscal year 2019, the immigration courts spent
approximately $728,575 in FedEx shipping costs.
grant funding delayed due to sanctuary city conditions
Question 10. In the Department's fiscal year 2020 Budget Hearing,
we discussed special conditions and bonus points applied to DOJ grants.
These conditions relate to Sanctuary Cities, and as I stated then, I
agree that the need for compliance with Federal law is paramount, but
so is the need to fight violent crime on the State and Local level. As
we discussed, several nationwide injunctions have been issued and are
being litigated; I also asked if there was a way to submit COPS Hiring
grant applications so that they may at least be reviewed while the
outcome of these cases is pending. You agreed to look into this, and I
appreciate that. Can you tell me if this is possible, or if there is
some other way to expedite the review and disbursement of 2018 and 2019
COPS Hiring grants?
Answer. In September 2017, the City of Los Angeles challenged the
Department of Justice's ability to use programmatic authority to
prioritize grant funding through the COPS Office. In April 2018, a
district court in California issued a nationwide injunction preventing
the Department of Justice from using its programmatic authority to
incentivize cooperation on immigration policy, a decision that the
Department immediately appealed in May 2018. Oral arguments were held
on August 30, 2018, and on July 12, 2019, the United States Court of
Appeals for the Ninth Circuit reversed the district court's ruling. The
Ninth Circuit held that the Department did not exceed its statutory
authority in awarding bonus points for immigration-focused priorities
or cooperation. On August 2, 2019, the City of Los Angeles filed a
Petition for Rehearing or Rehearing En Banc with the Ninth Circuit and
a decision on that petition is still pending. The Department filed a
Motion to Expedite the Issuance of Mandate, or to Stay the Injunction
Pending Issuance of Mandate on July 29, 2019, but that motion was
denied on August 27, 2019.
The COPS Office is working diligently to finalize a solicitation
for both fiscal year 2018 and fiscal year 2019 COPS Hiring Program
funding, with the intention of opening the program as soon as possible
following the issuance of the mandate lifting the injunction by the
Ninth Circuit. Once resolved, the Department and the COPS Office are
committed to acting as quickly as possible to expedite the program to
ensure these critical public safety dollars get directly into the hands
of State, local and Tribal law enforcement.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Jeanne Shaheen
bureau of prisons
Question 1. Over the past 2 years we've heard that the BOP has left
thousands of positions unfilled and I appreciate the Attorney General
finally lifting the hiring freeze for BOP. How many positions are
vacant for the 122 institutions across the country and how long have
these positions been unfilled? Please break out by institution, job
series and job title. What is DOJ's plan to speed up the hiring process
and bring an end to what is a longstanding and perennial problem of
understaffing in our Federal prisons?
Answer. While staffing at some Bureau institutions can be
challenging, particularly in institutions that are located remotely or
in areas where the prevailing wage is higher than the Federal pay
scale, the Bureau is committed to the goal of 100 percent staffing at
its facilities nationwide. To that end, the Bureau has put in place
recruitment and retention incentives at hard-to-fill locations, and has
instituted a nationwide incentive to retain retirement eligible staff.
These incentives are already bearing fruit. In March 2019, for the
first time since 2016, the Bureau had more staff hires than staff
departures, and this trend has continued each month since.
The Bureau has also put in place specialty incentives for certain
hard to recruit positions, such as physicians, nurses, dentists, and
psychologists. These include student loan repayment and specialty pay
rate incentives. Finally, the Bureau has recently been approved to use
3,000 temporary positions that will allow it to move forward more
expeditiously in filling vacancies.
Enclosed is a spreadsheet delineating current vacancies by
institution, job series, and job title. Data on how long a position has
been vacant is not tracked nationally and cannot be obtained.
[See total vacant and filled positions by location in attachment 3
in the appendix at the end of the hearing.]
[See vacant and filled positions BOP-wide by location in attachment
4 in the appendix at the end of the hearing.]
Question 2. For far too long, BOP used teachers, counselors and
other administrative staff as correctional officers--a practice known
as augmentation. This Committee has directed the BOP to significantly
curtail augmentation. What is your plan to accomplish that?
Answer. The safety of staff, inmates, and the public is the highest
priority for the BOP. BOP is working diligently to enhance its
recruitment efforts to increase its correctional officer complement. It
is currently trying to fill over 4,000 vacancies nationwide. While that
process will take time, BOP is making meaningful progress. BOP has made
almost 10,500 selections since March 2018, with hires exceeding
separations each month. They have established 10 percent recruitment,
relocation, and retention incentives at our hard-to-fill locations, and
a 5 percent nationwide retention incentive for retirement-eligible
employees. BOP has also established a higher entry pay scale for newly-
hired Correctional Officers for individuals who have relevant
experience. This pay scale should make these positions more attractive
for applicants who have solid correctional experience. BOP is also
using 3,000 temporary positions to provide for seamless transition as
staff promote or retire, avoiding the lag caused by waiting until the
position is vacant to begin the hiring process.
It is also important to bear in mind that, while BOP strives to
fill all of its correctional positions with full-time officers, all
staff assigned to correctional facilities are law enforcement officers
and are considered correctional workers first, regardless of their
occupation. All staff receive the same formal training (both initial
and continuing) as the correctional officers, and all staff are
informed at the time of hiring that they are expected to perform law
enforcement functions during routine and non-routine situations. Staff
correctional responsibilities precede all others. Accordingly, all
staff receive law enforcement pay and law enforcement retirement
benefits. When an insufficient number of correctional officers are
available to cover mission critical correctional posts, the BOP may
assign non-custody staff as officers to reduce the need to vacate posts
deemed critical for the safety and security of the institution. All
staff are made aware at the time of hiring that when BOP institutions
must use augmentation, this may curtail or delay the normal duties they
perform.
Question 3. When did development on the Risk and Needs Assessment,
the tool that's being used determine individual prisoners ``recidivism
risk'' required as part of the First Step Act, start? What is the
expected cost of IT development, deployment and usage for the Risk and
Needs Assessment for fiscal year 2020 and each year after that?
Answer. The Department was partially shut down until Friday,
January 25, 2019. Most of the staff working on First Step Act-related
projects were furloughed until that date, and nearly all FSA-related
work, including development of the Risk and Needs Assessment System,
did not qualify as excepted work that could be performed during a
partial shut down. When the Government reopened on Monday, January 28,
2019, the Department began the process of identifying organizations
that might serve as the Host Committee and worked to identify sources
of funding for the Independent Review Committee.
The Department is working with the administration and Congress to
ensure that necessary funds to implement the First Step Act--including
for IT development, deployment, and usage for the Risk and Needs
Assessment--will be available in fiscal year 2020 and beyond.
Question 4. The fiscal year 2020 budget request for BOP included
less than $100 million for the BOP's Buildings and Facilities (B&F)
account even though BOP's own list of ``Modernization and Repair
Unfunded Priorities'' totaled nearly $712 million. In light of this
large amount of unfunded M&R and some recent large and high-profile
issues regarding prison facilities, such as the heating and electrical
malfunction at MDC Brooklyn on some of the coldest days of the year and
the ongoing problem of arsenic in the water at USP Atlanta, what is
being done to proper M&R is covered?
Answer. Given the limited amount of funding provided to BOP's
Modernization and Repair Program, BOP must prioritize its needs.
Institution Facilities staff perform detailed annual inspections of all
areas and provide two lists of projects to the respective Regional
