Office identifying items in need of corrective action: one list of
projects costing less than $300,000 and one list of projects costing
more than $300,000. Regional Office staff review the justifications and
for those projects under $300,000 prioritize them to receive funding
from the regional office. For those projects costing more than
$300,000, a priority list is developed and sent to the Bureau's
headquarters or Central Office. Central Office reviews all projects
submitted from all six Bureau regional offices and identifies those
projects in need of funding. They are added to the M&R Unfunded
Priority List. With the assistance of the regional office staff, those
projects on the M&R Unfunded List in the most critical need are
identified and funding is allocated to as many as feasible. In
addition, as the fiscal year progresses, emergencies may arise. BOP
must re-prioritize needs in order to fund emergencies as they occur. At
times, funded projects may be canceled and those funds redirected to
cover the emergencies. BOP also identifies additional projects for
funding, to include emergencies, throughout the fiscal year as
contracts are awarded and costs are less than expected.
refugee vetting
I understand that Security Advisory Opinion (SAO) processing delays
are in part responsible for the administration's failure to reach even
half of its 45,000 refugee admissions goal in fiscal year 2018. The FBI
is integral to the refugee security vetting process and in particular,
SAO processing. The administration set a new record low admissions goal
of 30,000 in fiscal year 2019, and is on track to resettle only about
20,000 by the end of this fiscal year.
Question 5. Given administrative changes to the security process
for refugees--especially those from SAO countries--what increases in
the capacity of the FBI have happened and are still needed to restore a
robust refugee resettlement program?
Answer. The FBI is only one agency involved in the vetting process.
While an individual subject to a SAO may clear one agency, it may not
be cleared in another. The FBI can address only those SAOs it has
received and returned. The FBI is not the adjudicating agency and
provides relevant information to the adjudicating agency to inform
their determination. The FBI continues to support the Department of
State and the Department of Homeland Security as appropriate,
recognizing that it has only one small piece of the overall refugee
vetting program.
Question 6. What is the average time it takes to process one SAO,
and what is the current backlog of SAOs awaiting determination? Does
the FBI have any benchmarks or goals for processing times?
Answer. The FBI vets SAO Merlins, which are a subset of refugee
applicants subject to additional screening based on potential threats
and national security concerns. These requests are worked on a first-
in/first-out workflow system and require in-depth review of not just
principal applicants but also their family and associates. A thorough
manual review of one application can take a vetting analyst 1 day or up
to several days, depending on the number of individuals listed and the
complexity of the application, and whether or not derogatory
information is identified. The Department of State and USCIS will often
request the FBI to expedite the review of certain cases, which the FBI
prioritizes ahead of those already in the workflow system. In the
instances that the application is relatively straightforward, the FBI
is able to complete its process quickly. From October 1, 2018 to March
31, 2019, the FBI was able to return responses on more than 5,000
applications where no derogatory information was identified. The total
number of refugees in the USRAP pipeline is unknown to the FBI.
Question 7. Will any new staffing or reassignment of staff be
required to carry out these new requirements?
Answer. There are currently a total of 28 FBI agents, professional
staff, and contractors dedicated solely to vetting refugees, which is a
significant increase over prior years' staffing levels. However, this
current resource level is not sufficient to guarantee that all of the
refugee applications are completed in a timely manner.
The FBI has been working on technological enhancements to clear
applicants with no derogatory information in FBI holdings faster and
the 2020 budget requests additional automation enhancements and
personnel for manual reviews.
Question 8. How might Congress seek to increase capacity at the FBI
in order to see the USRAP operate in a timely manner, so that the
fiscal year 2019 (and fiscal year 2020) admissions goal(s) can be met?
Answer. The FBI is supporting the National Vetting Center (NVC)
pursuant to the President's National Security Memorandum. The FBI has
prioritized the NVC above any technical upgrades to the refugee vetting
process. Even though the FBI's process for reviewing SAO Merlins
changed in 2016, the processing time has consistently remained the
same. The new process is more thorough and entails a review of not only
principal applications, but also family members and associates.
Therefore, a thorough review for one application can take up to several
days. Though the level of effort the FBI applies to each application
increased in 2016, the FBI has shifted internal resources to maintain
consistent processing times. As of November 2019, the FBI has nearly
completed its backlog of SAO Merlin applications. The 2020 Budget
requests additional resources to hire additional personnel for the
manual reviews and to work on technological enhancements to further
automate the process.
Question 9. Recent Special Immigrant Visa arrivals represent a more
than 60 percent drop compared to average monthly arrivals in fiscal
year 2017, despite the fact that Afghan SIVs have not been subject to
the same pauses and additional vetting procedures DHS has instituted
for other countries and for refugee populations more broadly. Total SIV
arrivals overall in the first few months of fiscal year 2019 show that
the U.S. is not on track to resettling the number of Afghan SIVs it
planned for this year. How is DOJ working to ensure Afghan SIVs
continue to be processed in a timely manner?
Answer. Under its new vetting structure, the FBI has been
constantly working since summer 2018 to refine the processes in such a
way that will allow for the most efficient and accurate vetting of the
Special Immigrant Visa (SIV) population. From June to December 2018,
the FBI vetted 640 SIV applicants. Since January 2019, the FBI has
vetted 3,150 SIV applicants.
Question 10. U.S.-affiliated Iraqis (Iraqi P-2s) are individuals
who provided critical services, like translation, to U.S. missions
abroad and now face persecution as a result. Conservative estimates
suggest that there are tens of thousands of Iraqis with close
affiliations with the U.S. Government waiting for interviews to have
their cases for resettlement processed. What is DOJ doing to increase
the number of U.S.-affiliated Iraqis who arrive this year and next?
Answer. The FBI continues to work with the Department of State and
Department of Defense to mitigate potential derogatory information for
the Priority-2 Iraqi population. The FBI does not track individuals who
provided translation or other services separately.
wire act
Question 11. The Office of Legal Counsel recently released a memo
that reinterpreted the Wire Act in a way that has put both Internet
lottery sales and brick-and-mortar sales of traditional lottery at risk
of being considered in violation of the Act. Billions of dollars
generated annually from lottery proceeds fund worthy causes including
public education in States like New Hampshire.
The Supreme Court also indicated its agreement with two Federal
circuit courts of appeal that held the Act applies solely to betting or
wagering on sports events, and further noted the importance of Federal
policy respecting the policy choices of citizens in each individual
State. State lotteries are authorized and regulated by State law;
operated by the State or the State's statutory designee; conducted by
licensed lottery retailers or through legal Internet channels of
distribution that are within the State; and purchased only by persons
physically present within the State.
I appreciate that DOJ extended the enforcement moratorium on the
memo in light of the suit filed by the New Hampshire Lottery
Commission. I also understand that DOJ is currently reviewing whether
the Wire Act applies to State lotteries and their vendors.
What steps does DOJ plan to take to clarify that the Wire Act is
not intended to prohibit the operations of State lotteries whether
online or in-person sales?
Answer. The Wire Act was enacted in 1961, decades before State
lotteries sought to sell tickets over the Internet. Should Congress
wish to ensure that the Wire Act does not prohibit State lotteries and
their vendors from using the Internet for online sales, then Congress
could amend the terms of the Wire Act and accomplish the result.
Congress has previously adopted such measures to create exemptions from
other Federal laws regulating gambling and lotteries. See, e.g., 18
U.S.C. 1307; 1953(b)(4).
The Department is currently involved in litigation concerning
whether Section 1084(a) of the Wire Act applies exclusively to sports
gambling. On June 3, 2019, a Federal district court held that it is so
limited, and the Department's appeal is now pending. With respect to
State lotteries, the Deputy Attorney General issued a memorandum on
April 8, 2019 directing Department attorneys to refrain from applying
Section 1084(a) to State lotteries and their vendors, if they are
operating as authorized by State law. The memorandum provides that, if
the Department determines that the Wire Act does apply to State
lotteries or their vendors, then Department attorneys should extend the
forbearance period for 90 days after the Department publicly announces
this position. This would allow Congress a reasonable time to amend the
statute, should it choose to do so, or otherwise allow State lotteries
and their vendors to conform their operations to Federal law.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Susan M. Collins
regional information sharing system
Question 1. The Regional Information Sharing System, known as
``RISS,'' is a program that links thousands of criminal justice
agencies through secure communications and information sharing services
to help combat multi-jurisdictional crimes. I'll give you an example:
Law enforcement officials in Auburn, Maine, used the RISS databases to
solve a local break-in. They were able to identify the stolen items
through RISS, and ultimately locate and arrest two suspects who had
fled to Florida. Despite the proven effectiveness of this program, this
year's budget requests cutting funding for RISS. Looking forward, will
DOJ prioritize support for RISS, which has proven to effectively serve
the law enforcement community?
Answer. I appreciate your interest in RISS, and we will take this
information into consideration in future budget requests as we
determine how to address an array of funding priorities for DOJ. In
fiscal year 2020, the President's budget prioritizes resources
addressing violent crime prevention and reduction. While the six
regional centers that make up the Regional Information Sharing System
offer a range of justice information sharing and investigative support
services, only part of their activities are focused on addressing
violent and drug-related crime. The $10 million request for RISS in the
fiscal year 2020 President's budget will continue to provide support
for those efforts.
opioid crisis
Question 2. Congress has increased funding and Federal efforts year
after year to combat the opioid crisis, yet the Department's budget,
once again, proposes eliminating the COPS Anti-Heroin Task Forces. Why
does the Department propose eliminating the program, which has helped
local law enforcement partners take on the opioid crisis?
Answer. Combating the opioid epidemic is a top priority for the
Department and the administration. To ensure more streamlined efforts
throughout the Federal Government to combat this issue and avoid
duplicative efforts, no funding is requested in fiscal year 2020 by the
COPS Office for the Anti-Heroin Task Force program. By redirecting this
funding, the Department will be able to increase resources toward
supporting other mission critical initiatives, such as Federal funding
for DEA prescription opioid and heroin enforcement programs.
anti-semitism
Question 3. I am a strong supporter of the U.S.-Israel
relationship, and I recognize there are many legitimate criticisms of
Israel and various Israeli governments. However, groups and individuals
have often hid under the veil of legitimate criticism of Israel to
express hateful and harmful anti-Semitic rhetoric. Jews and people of
all faiths in the United States stand at risk of injury and harm as
these anti-Semitic tropes and expressions become normalized in American
discourse. The Justice Department is tasked with defining anti-Semitism
and enforcing Federal hate-crime legislation. Could you discuss the
importance of addressing certain anti-Israel activity in the
Department's definition of anti-Semitism?
Answer. Combatting anti-Semitism is an important priority for me
and for the Department of Justice. We hosted a summit on the topic in
July. As I stated then, I am deeply concerned about the rise in hate
crimes and political violence that we have seen over the past decade,
including a marked increase in reported instances of anti-Semitic hate
crimes.
The Department's main role in combatting anti-Semitism comes in the
prosecution of hate crimes. Federal hate-crime laws cover threats or
attacks motivated by animus based on race, religion, and national
origin (among other attributes), whether actual or perceived. The
Department therefore prosecutes crimes committed out of anti-Jewish or
anti-Israeli attitudes as hate crimes. In such cases, we must prove
beyond a reasonable doubt that the defendant acted because of anti-
Jewish or anti-Israeli bias as a ``but for'' motivating factor for the
crime. We evaluate such matters on a case-by-case basis, and look at
the full facts and context of each incident, including statements made
by the alleged perpetrator, to determine if the crime was in fact
motivated by anti-Jewish or anti-Israeli bias.
I thus agree that anti-Israel activity can cross the line from
criticism of policies of the Israel Government into anti-Semitism. For
example, at the Department's summit in July, I noted that, ``[o]n
college campuses today, Jewish students who support Israel are
frequently targeted for harassment, Jewish student organizations are
marginalized, and progressive Jewish students are told they must
denounce their beliefs and their heritage in order be part of
'intersectional' causes.'' While the First Amendment sometimes limits
what the Government can do, the Department will not shy away from
prosecuting hate crimes where appropriate. Ultimately, we depend on our
society as a whole to reject anti-Semitism in all of its forms and to
change the hearts and minds of those who harbor it.
iran sanctions
Question 4. The Trump administration has imposed strong sanctions
on Iran as part of the President's Iran strategy, and the Justice
Department plays a vital role in enforcing these sanctions. Several
cases over the last 5 years have shown the willingness of large
companies to violate U.S. sanctions when faced with lax enforcement. Do
you intend to make the prosecution of Iran sanctions violations a
priority?
Answer. The Department of Justice vigorously works to disrupt
violations of U.S. sanctions and export controls related to Iran and
Hezbollah. The Department, including the Federal Bureau of
Investigation, has consistently and aggressively investigated and
prosecuted Iran sanctions violations and will continue to do so. Iran
sanctions matters comprise more than 40 percent of all export control
and sanctions cases that the Department handles nationwide--more than
any other single foreign jurisdiction.
hezbollah
Question 5. The terrorist organization Hezbollah has claimed the
lives of more Americans than any terror group other than Al-Qaeda, and
continues to pose a significant threat to the United States and its
allies. In addition to terror, Hezbollah maintains a vast criminal
network that proliferates weapons, traffics narcotics, and launders
money around the globe, Former Attorney General Sessions labelled
Hezbollah as a top transnational criminal organization priority for the
Justice Department. How is the Justice Department in 2019 continuing to
fight Hezbollah and maintain the high urgency of prosecutions?
Answer. The Department's Hezbollah Financing and Narcoterrorism
Team (HFNT), created by former Attorney General Sessions, continues to
do important work and meet with partners as appropriate to advance
investigations and prosecutions of Hezbollah-related targets around the
country. In May 2019, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern
District of New York obtained the first U.S. conviction of an operative
of the Islamic Jihad Organization, a component of Hezbollah, on
terrorism charges. In August 2019, the Criminal Division's Money
Laundering and Asset Recovery Section completed the prosecution of
Kassim Tajideen, who was designated by OFAC as a Specially Designated
Global Terrorist in 2009 based upon his tens of millions of dollars of
financial support of Hezbollah. Tajideen operated a multi-billion-
dollar commodity distribution business primarily in the Middle East and
Africa through a web of vertically integrated companies, partnerships,
and trade names. He conspired to conduct over $50 million in
transactions with U.S. businesses that violated these prohibitions.
Tajideen pled guilty to money laundering conspiracy, is serving 5 years
in prison, and agreed to pay $50 million in forfeiture in advance of
his sentencing, which he did. The Department also continues to engage
actively in overseas capacity-building with our foreign law enforcement
partners engaged in the fight against Hezbollah, including at a June
2019 law enforcement coordination workshop bringing together Department
representatives with counterparts from Interpol, Ameripol, Argentina,
Peru, Colombia, Panama, Paraguay, and Chile, among others.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Lindsey Graham
first step act
Question 1. The FIRST STEP Act was a monumental, bipartisan
accomplishment that works to reduce recidivism, improve the reentry of
inmates back into society, and reform sentencing for certain nonviolent
Federal offenses.
The law authorizes $75 million to implement the provisions of the
FIRST STEP Act, yet the funding request is $15 million. Why did the
Department request this funding level?
Answer. As you know, the First Step Act was signed into law on
December 21, 2018 and as such the President's fiscal year 2020 budget
request had already been formulated. While the full scope of resources
needed to implement the First Step Act (FSA) continues to be evaluated,
the fiscal year 2020 President's budget included $16.5 million as an
initial investment, including $15 million for the Bureau of Prisons and
$1.5 million for the National Institute of Justice.
On July 19, 2019, the Department announced the re-direction of $75
million in existing funds for FSA implementation in fiscal year 2019.
The Department has worked with the CJS subcommittee on fiscal year 2020
First Step Act resource needs, totaling $116.1 million. Both the fiscal
year 2020 Senate and House Marks provide $75 million for the First Step
Act. We continue to work with the subcommittee on needs for the First
Step Act upon request.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Patrick J. Leahy
special counsel's report
Question 1. During your testimony on April 10, I asked whether you
spoke with Special Counsel Mueller about his decision not to arrive at
a conclusion with respect to obstruction of justice; you confirmed that
such a conversation took place. You stated that he didn't express to
you any expectation or interest in leaving the obstruction question to
Congress, but that he also didn't say that the obstruction decision
should be left to up you.
1a. Now that you have released a redacted version of the Special
Counsel's report, with as much detail as your memory allows, please
describe what Special Counsel Mueller told you--and what you told him--
during that conversation about why he didn't arrive at a conclusion on
the obstruction of justice question, and how--and by whom--that
question should be resolved.
Answer. I transmitted a letter to Congressional leaders on March
24, 2019, which provided the principal conclusions reached by Special
Counsel Robert Mueller, including as to the obstruction-of-justice
issue central to Volume II of the Special Counsel's ``Report on the
Investigation Into Russian Interference In The 2016 Presidential
Election.'' This letter is enclosed.
[See the letter of March 24, 2019, in attachment 1 in the appendix
at the end of the hearing.]
On April 18, 2019, I released a version of the Special Counsel's
confidential report to the public. As I explained in my letter of the
same date to the Chairmen and Ranking Members of the Senate Judiciary
Committee and House Judiciary Committee, the public report is ``subject
only to those redactions required by the law or compelling law
enforcement, national security, or personal privacy interests.'' In
addition, I have made a minimally redacted version of the Special
Counsel's report available to certain congressional leaders and staff.
The public report, which addresses Special Counsel Mueller's reasons
for not reaching a conclusion about obstruction of justice, speaks for
itself.
In addition to the report, Special Counsel Mueller has made public
statements and given congressional testimony about his investigation,
report, and findings. Those statements speak for themselves.
1b. Was there any written correspondence between Special Counsel
Mueller and his team and the Justice Department with respect to why he
did not arrive at a conclusion on the obstruction of justice question?
If so, can you provide this Committee with copies of such
correspondence?
Answer. Special Counsel Mueller addressed this issue in his
confidential report, which I have since made public, as well as in
public statements and congressional testimony. The public report,
statements, and testimony speak for themselves.
Question 2. During your testimony on April 10, you stated that
``the court can only waive 6(e)'' grand jury secrecy ``for one of the
grounds specifically in 6(e).'' But there are avenues for disclosure
under Rule 6(e) that do not require any action from a court. Rule
6(e)(3)(D), for example, allows the Attorney General--without the prior
approval of a court--to release grand jury material to ``any
appropriate Federal . . . official, for the purpose of preventing or
responding to'' foreign threats or hostile acts.
2a. Have you considered Rule 6(e)(3)(D) for disclosure of grand
jury material?
Answer. The Department understands and takes very seriously the
Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, including the confidentiality
requirements under Rule 6. The Department addressed this issue in a
June 12, 2019 letter to Representative Adam Schiff, Chairman of the
House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence, which is enclosed.
[See the letter of June 12, 2019, in attachment 2 in the appendix
at the end of the hearing.]
2b. Do you agree that Members of Congress--and certainly relevant
committees, such as the Judiciary, Intelligence, Foreign Relations, and
Appropriations committees--have a significant role to play in
``responding to'' and ``preventing'' attacks on our elections by
hostile foreign actors?
Answer. Please see the enclosed June 12, 2019 letter to Chairman
Adam Schiff.
Question 3. In the FOIA context, courts have repeatedly found that
the executive branch has waived executive privilege through informal
statements that contain no explicit mention of a waiver, including: (1)
the executive's representations about purportedly privileged materials;
(2) use of those representations to convince the public; and (3) an
overlap between what has been disclosed and what is purportedly
privileged.
Has the Justice Department applied the President's repeated claims
about the Russia investigation to this standard? Did the President not
waive any claims to executive privilege through his repeated, public
discussions of this investigation?
Answer. Executive privilege has several components, including the
national security, deliberative process, law enforcement, attorney-
client, and presidential communications components. The legal standards
governing waiver of each of these components differ in important ways,
and the Department carefully analyzes these doctrines prior to making,
recommending, or defending any assertion of privilege.
2020 census
Question 4. The Census Act includes strict confidentiality
protections for personal data. Public confidence in the statutory
promise that personal information cannot be shared or used against an
individual for any purpose, including law enforcement, is critical for
a successful census.
With the 2020 Census less than a year away, will you commit to
ensuring that the Justice Department will take no steps to violate
these confidentiality protections, and will not allow an end-run around
those protections via Executive Order or a reinterpretation of the law?
Answer. As the Department has consistently maintained, the
Department will abide by all laws that protect the confidentiality of
personal data collected through the 2020 Census.
zero tolerance policy
Question 5. When you were asked your views about the ``zero
tolerance'' prosecution policy implemented by Attorney General Sessions
at your confirmation hearing, you stated that because you were ``not in
the department,'' you didn't ``know all the details.''
Now that you have been in charge of the Department for 2 months,
does the Department have evidence to demonstrate that the zero
tolerance policy had any measurable deterrent effect on illegal
crossings at our southwest border? If so, please share with this
Committee.
Answer. The Zero Tolerance Prosecution Initiative directs the U.S.
Attorney's Offices along the Southwest Border, to the extent
practicable and in consultation with DHS, to adopt a zero-tolerance
policy for all offenses referred for prosecution under 8 U.S.C.
Sec. 1325(a). The prosecution policy is still in place and therefore,
its full effects have yet to be seen. I will note that, in fiscal year
2018, the number of defendants prosecuted under Section 1325(a)
surpassed 60,000 for the first time since fiscal year 2014.
anti-heroin task force grants
Question 6. The Trump administration's fiscal year 2020 budget
request zeroes out all funding for Anti-Heroin Task Force grants. These
grants, which we appropriated at $32 million in fiscal year 2019,
support law enforcement task forces disrupting drug trafficking
organizations to keep heroin and other opioids out of our communities.
6a. Was the Department consulted about the administration's
decision to zero out all funding for Anti-Heroin Task Force grants in
its 2020 budget request? Did you include funding in your original
request, but the passback the Department received from the Office of
Management and Budget (OMB) eliminated the funding?
Answer. The Executive Branch communications that led to the
President's budgetary decisions are confidential and may not be
disclosed either by the Department or by those who have prepared the
budget.
6b. Does the Department not consider these grants critical to
efforts combatting our opioid epidemic?
Answer. Combating the opioid epidemic is a top priority for the
Department and the administration. To ensure more streamlined efforts
throughout the Federal Government to combat this issue and avoid
duplicative efforts, no funding is requested in fiscal year 2020 by the
COPS Office for the Anti-Heroin Task Force program. By redirecting this
funding, the Department will be able to increase resources toward
supporting other mission critical initiatives, such as providing $11.1
million in additional Federal funding for DEA prescription opioid and
heroin enforcement programs. This will allow DEA to fund 5 new heroin
enforcement groups and add 35 new DEA agents.
Question 7. Between the Justice Department's testimony before House
appropriators on April 9, Senate appropriators on April 10, and the
Acting Director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and
Explosives' testimony before the House last month, it is clear that
there is a difference in opinion between the Department and ATF on the
impact of the President's fiscal year 2020 budget on ATF personnel. The
concern is that the slight budget increase allocated to the ATF in the
President's budget will be fully consumed by program increases and a
$25 million budget shortfall from last year, which will result in
losses of more than 370 ATF personnel in the coming year through
attrition.
Can you commit to protecting ATF by doing everything you can to
ensure the Bureau does not lose agents or other personnel through the
coming budget cycle, taking into account expected losses from
attrition?
Answer. The Department and ATF are working together to ensure that
ATF can support program increases in critical areas while maintaining
agent levels at the number proposed in the fiscal year 2020 President's
Budget. A final determination regarding the allocation of ATF's
resources is dependent on the funding received in fiscal year 2020, but
agent hiring will remain a Departmental priority.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Dianne Feinstein
voting rights
Question 1. In response to Questions for the Record submitted after
your confirmation hearing, you wrote that you would make the protection
of civil rights and voting rights ``a priority for the Department'' if
you were confirmed. (Barr Response, DF QFR 49)
Since becoming Attorney General, what specific steps have you taken
to make the protection of voting rights a priority for the Justice
Department?
Answer. The Department is committed to the zealous and evenhanded
enforcement of the Federal voting laws and to free and fair elections
for all Americans. Since I was sworn in as Attorney General, the
Department has carried out that mission all across the country. In June
2019, the Department entered into a consent decree to resolve its
lawsuit in United States v. Eastpointe, which the United States filed
to protect the voting rights of African Americans under Section 2 of
the Voting Rights Act. The United States had alleged that the at-large
method of electing city councilmembers in Eastpointe, Michigan
illegally diluted African-American voting strength in violation of
Section 2. The consent decree between the United States and the City
resolves that violation and was entered by the district court on June
28, 2019.
In February 2019, the Department entered into a memorandum of
understanding with the State of Connecticut under the Help America Vote
Act (HAVA) and the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA). That
memorandum of understanding will ensure that the State fulfills its
Federal-law obligation to coordinate its statewide voter registration
database with Connecticut Department of Public Health Records to
identify and remove from the voter rolls individuals who have died.
Additionally, the Department has entered into settlement agreements
with four local jurisdictions under the Americans with Disabilities Act
to ensure that those jurisdictions provide access at the polling place
to voters with disabilities. One of those settlements resolved long-
running litigation with Harris County, Texas, whose voting program--the
third largest in the country--includes over 750 polling places. Two of
those settlements--with McKinley County, New Mexico and Sandoval
County, New Mexico--cover polling places on Tribal lands. The final
agreement was reached with Concord, New Hampshire. All of these
settlements are part of the Department's ADA Voting Initiative, which
focuses on protecting the voting rights of individuals with
disabilities and, to date, has resulted in Department surveys of more
than 1,600 polling places and increased polling place accessibility in
more than 35 jurisdictions.
Question 2. In Questions for the Record for your confirmation
hearing, I asked about President Trump's claims regarding alleged voter
fraud. As I noted in my question to you, President Trump said on the
day before the election that ``[t]here are a lot of people--a lot of
people--my opinion, and based on proof--that try and get in illegally
and actually vote illegally.'' (Washington Post story quoting Trump
(Nov. 5, 2018)) I asked if you were aware of any evidence that ``a lot
of people'' vote illegally. You responded that you had not studied the
issue raised ``in great detail'' and that you were not familiar with
the data or statistics on the matter.
2a. Now that you have been in office, have you found any data
supporting this claim? Are you aware of any evidence that ``a lot of
people'' vote illegally? If so, what is it?
Answer. I am aware that people do vote illegally and that the
Department investigates and prosecutes such cases where appropriate.
For instance, the Eastern District of North Carolina has, upon
predication from local election authorities, and through investigation
by the Department of Homeland Security, initiated at least 20 alien
voting cases, including both felony and misdemeanor offenses.
2b. Are you concerned that statements like this undermine the
public's faith in election results?
Answer. It is my hope that all members of the public have faith
that any properly predicated cases of illegal voting will be
investigated and prosecuted pursuant to the Principles of Federal
Prosecution.
extreme risk protection orders
Question 3. At your confirmation hearing, you stated that: ``I also
think we need to push along the [Extreme Risk Protection Orders] so
that we have these red flag laws to supplement the use of the
background check to find out if someone has a mental disturbance. This
is the single most important thing I think we can do in the gun control
area to stop these massacres from happening in the first place.''
Will you support enactment of my bill (S. 506) to create grants to
incentivize States into creating their own extreme-risk laws?
Answer. The Federal Commission on School Safety, of which the
Department was a member, recommended that States adopt Extreme Risk
Protection Order (ERPO) laws that incorporate an appropriate
evidentiary standard and protect due process and Second Amendment
rights. Seventeen States and the District of Columbia have already
passed ERPO laws, and many others are actively considering them. The
Department would be pleased to review your legislation on this issue.
domestic violence and firearms
Question 4. Many domestic violence abusers who have been convicted
of a misdemeanor crime or are subject to a protection order are still
able to stockpile an arsenal of firearms and ammunition--despite being
prohibited from possessing either under Federal firearms law.
Local domestic violence programs often attempt to help victims by
seeking enforcement of Federal law and removal of the firearms, but
they are unable to get assistance from the Department of Justice and
other Federal agencies.
4a. What steps have you taken to improve the Department of
Justice's response to cases like these? If none, will you commit to
correcting this?
Answer. The Department is committed to enforcing Federal gun laws
and to ensuring that prohibited persons--including those ``convicted in
any court of a misdemeanor crime of domestic violence"--do not possess
firearms.
On November 13, 2019, I announced Project Guardian, which is a
nationwide strategic plan to reduce gun violence. While many aspects of
Project Guardian should help in this area, the plan includes specific
emphasis on enforcing the background-check requirement for purchases by
those convicted of domestic violence misdemeanors or against whom a
protective order has been issued. Project Guardian also includes
measures to improve the information in the NICS database to make it
easier to identify prohibited persons who attempt to purchase firearms.
Other DOJ efforts help as well. Training on the Federal domestic
violence gun laws is included in all violent crime and Project Safe
Neighborhoods (PSN) trainings. In addition, Violence Against Women Act
points of contact are kept apprised of all legal developments in this
area to assist in the implementation of these laws. DOJ is also seeking
to broaden these domestic violence firearms prohibitions to include,
for example, local convictions--as suggested in the VAWA
Reauthorization Bill--which would enhance DOJ's ability to protect all
domestic violence victims.
While there is always room to improve, DOJ has done significant
work to address firearm possession by domestic violence offenders. In
fiscal year 2017, ATF initiated 2,648 field investigations based upon
referrals from the National Instant Criminal Background Check System
(NICS) involving allegations of the attempted acquisition or actual
acquisition of a firearm by a person convicted of a misdemeanor crime
of domestic violence. In fiscal year 2018, ATF initiated 2,596 of these
types of investigations and in the first quarter of fiscal year 2019
alone, ATF initiated 1,264 of these types of investigations. The number
of cases prosecuted under the Federal domestic violence gun laws
continues to rise.
4b. What kind of resources are you devoting to make sure that guns
are not as accessible to domestic abusers?
Answer. In June 2019, the Department announced the creation of a
Domestic Violence Working Group aimed at keeping guns out of the hands
of domestic abusers, using the tools of Federal prosecution to stop and
prevent domestic abuse. However, DOJ's task to prosecute abusers with
firearms has been made more challenging by the Supreme Court decision
in Rehaif v. US, requiring the government in gun possession cases to
prove not only a defendant's knowledge of gun possession but also of
the status that makes the defendant prohibited. This decision will
require significant outreach to our State, local and Tribal partners to
try and ensure that this knowledge is communicated during State, local
and Tribal proceedings. It will also require significant resources as
USAOs respond to challenges from previously convicted domestic violence
misdemeanants under the Gun Control Act.
The Department is also working to support the work of State and
local officials on this issue. Since 2016, the Department's Office on
Violence Against Women (OVW) has partnered with the Battered Women's
Justice Project (BWJP) to establish a national resource center on
domestic violence and firearms. The project provides resources and
training for relevant disciplines, including victim advocates, civil
attorneys, prosecutors, and law enforcement officers, about preventing
gun possession by domestic violence offenders and has a website,
https://www.preventdvgunviolence.org/, with comprehensive resources and
information. OVW is also working with the National Council of Juvenile
and Family Court Judges on an initiative to provide a small number of
pilot sites with intensive training and technical assistance on
enforcement of laws to prevent domestic abusers' access to firearms.
immigration
Question 5. President Trump stated last week that the United States
should ``get rid of judges''--specifically immigration judges--and
``get rid of the whole asylum system.''
5a. Do you agree that we should ``get rid of'' immigration judges?
If so, who should adjudicate immigration cases?
Answer. EOIR's mission is to adjudicate immigration cases by
fairly, expeditiously, and uniformly interpreting and administering the
Nation's immigration laws. This includes cases involving detained
aliens, criminal aliens, and aliens seeking asylum as a form of relief
from removal, while ensuring the standards of due process and fair
treatment for all parties involved.
The asylum system is being overwhelmed by the burdens created as
the result of increased apprehension and processing of hundreds of
thousands of aliens along the southern border. The majority of these
aliens do not have meritorious asylum claims. The increase in
apprehensions along the southern border has increased the immigration
court backlog, delayed the removal of those without a valid basis to
remain in the United States, and frustrated those who do have valid
claims to remain. The Department stands ready to work with Congress to
address the many inefficiencies in the immigration system and to ensure
that claims are addressed expeditiously and consistent with due
process.
5b. Do you agree that we should ``get rid of the whole asylum
system''?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 5(a) above.
Question 6. Immigration courts face an unprecedented backlog of
over 800,000 pending cases. As a result of a decision by Attorney
General Sessions in 2018, immigration judges are no longer able to
manage their dockets. Judges are now required to reopen approximately
350,000 cases that were previously closed, for immigrants who pose no
danger to the community. As a result, the backlog of cases is likely to
increase to well over 1 million.
Would you commit to allowing immigration judges to manage their
dockets by giving them flexibility to close cases where immigrants are
eligible for visas that would protect them from deportation?
Answer. The decision to limit administrative closure of cases in
2018 was based on a determination that immigration judges generally
lack the legal authority to close cases in that way. Experience also
showed that administrative closures did not help to reduce the backlog
of cases, as the backlog of cases increased by over 400,000 in the
approximately 6 years that immigration judges exercised such authority.
I do not believe that discretionary administrative closures represent a
sound docket-management policy.
Question 7. This week you ruled that people who have established a
credible fear of persecution or torture cannot be released on bond
while they wait for months and years for their immigration court case
to proceed. In doing so, you overruled a binding decision of the Board
of Immigration Appeals and created a de facto new category of mandatory
detention.
7a. Can asylum seekers who establish a credible fear of persecution
or torture be granted parole from detention while their immigration
cases are pending if they arrive in the U.S. between ports-of-entry?
Answer. In Matter of M-S-, 27 I&N Dec. 509 (A.G. 2019), I
determined that an alien who is transferred from expedited removal
proceedings to full removal proceedings after establishing a credible
fear of persecution or torture is ineligible for release on bond and
must be detained unless paroled under section 215(d)(5)(A) of the INA.
That decision is the subject of active ongoing litigation, and in
accordance with longstanding Department policy, it would not be
appropriate to comment on it further. Because parole decisions
regarding aliens are made by the Department of Homeland Security (DHS),
I would respectfully defer any specific questions about the parole
process to DHS.
7b. Are those asylum seekers subject to mandatory detention? Does
such mandatory detention before an immigration hearing without a bond
hearing violate the Constitution, including the due process clause of
5th Amendment?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 7(a) above.
7c. Given that the administration has limited capacity at ports-of-
entry and asylum seekers are waiting months to enter the U.S. to
express a fear of persecution or torture, do asylum seekers have a
realistic chance at receiving parole?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 7(a) above.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Jack Reed
foreign meddling in u.s. elections
Question 1. Do you agree with the unanimous assessment of our
Intelligence community that: ``Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered
an influence campaign in 2016 aimed at the U.S. presidential election.
Russia's goals were to undermine public faith in the U.S. democratic
process, denigrate Secretary Clinton, and harm her electability and
potential presidency'', and that ``Putin and the Russian Government
developed a clear preference for President-elect Trump.''
Answer. I agree that Russia took steps to interfere with the 2016
presidential election.
Question 2. Do you agree that the Russian Military Intelligence
units or GRU, hacked ``into the computers of U.S. persons and entities
involved in the 2016 presidential election, stole documents, and timed
the release of that stolen information to interfere with the 2016
presidential election'' as concluded in the Special Counsel's
indictment from July 2018?
Answer. The Department announced on July 13, 2018, that a Federal
grand jury in the District of Columbia returned an indictment charging
12 Russian military officers for conspiring to interfere with the 2016
presidential election. Consistent with longstanding Department policy
and practice, it would not be appropriate for me to comment further on
this pending matter.
Question 3. Do you agree that the Kremlin-linked troll organization
known as the Internet Research Agency: ``knowingly and intentionally
conspired...to defraud the United States by impairing, obstructing and
defeating the lawful functions of the government through fraud and
deceit for the purpose of interfering with the U.S. political and
electoral processes, including the presidential election of 2016,'' as
concluded by the Special Counsel's indictment of February 2018?
Answer. On February 16, 2018, a grand jury in the District of
Columbia returned an indictment charging 13 Russian nationals and three
companies, including Internet Research Agency, LLC, for seeking to
interfere with the U.S. political system, including the 2016 U.S.
presidential election. Consistent with longstanding Department policy
and practice, it would not be appropriate for me to comment further on
this pending matter.
Question 4. Was it correct for the Intelligence Community to
investigate the threats at the time they were occurring? Would you
define such actions as ``spying''?
Answer. There are two pending reviews at the Department of Justice,
one by the Office of the Inspector General and one by U.S. Attorney
John Durham, that relate to the investigation of Russian interference
in the 2016 Presidential election. Consistent with longstanding
Department policy and practice, it would not be appropriate for me to
comment further while those reviews remain pending.
Question 5. You acknowledged in response to my question that you
have no specific evidence of any impropriety in the FBI's
counterintelligence investigation begun in 2016, nor do you have any
specific evidence of any impropriety in the investigation as carried
out by Special Counsel Mueller.
Given the lack of evidence, why did you choose to repeatedly state
that you believe ``spying did occur''?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 4 above.
Question 6. What specific ``spying'' action or actions, by which
agencies or persons, were you referring to? And what specific evidence
do you have to support you claim of concerns that the investigation may
not be ``adequately predicated?''
Answer. Please see my response to Question 4 above.
Question 7. Is it your belief that our Intelligence Community
should investigate threats of foreign interference in the 2020
election? Do you believe that such actions would constitute ``spying''?
Answer. Counterintelligence activities, including
counterintelligence investigations of any threats of malign foreign
influence targeting the 2020 election, remains a critically important
area for the Department and the Intelligence Community. In light of the
efforts that foreign intelligence services made to influence previous
elections, the FBI established a Foreign Influence Task Force (FITF) in
2017 to investigate and combat malign foreign influence, including
efforts to interfere with election infrastructure. The FITF works
closely with the Intelligence Community to investigate those threats
and will continue to do so through the 2020 election.
russian interference
Question 8. Russia is attacking our democracy using hybrid warfare
and malign influence operations. The Justice Department has worked to
expose these operations. The Special Counsel, Mr. Mueller, has worked
with the Western District of Pennsylvania and separately with the
Eastern District of Virginia to secure indictments of Russian Military
Intelligence units (GRU) and the Kremlin-linked troll organization,
known as the Internet Research Agency.
Attorney General Barr, do you concur with the Director of National
Intelligence Coats' assessment that Russian hybrid warfare operations
are: ``persistent, ongoing'' and have the intent ``to undermine
America's democracy on a daily basis, regardless of whether it is
election time or not''?
Answer. I share concerns about the efforts of the Russian
government to interfere in our elections and to undermine our
democracy. The Department of Justice is committed to opposing these
efforts in cooperation with the Intelligence Community. For further
information, please see my answer to the preceding question.
Question 9. Do you support a whole of government approach to
counter and deter Russian hybrid warfare operations against the United
States, our allies, and partners?
Answer. I support a whole-of-government approach that works closely
with our allies and partners to counter and deter Russian
disinformation and malign influence operations in our election system
and democratic processes.
Question 10. As described in last summer's report of the Attorney
General's Cyber Digital Task Force: ``[t]he Department of Justice has a
significant role in investigating and disrupting foreign government
activity in the United States that threatens U.S. national security. In
particular, the Department has an important role in identifying and
combatting malign influence operations and in enforcing Federal laws
that foreign agents may violate when engaging in such operations.''
Has the President directed you to take action to counter and blunt
Russian hybrid warfare and malign influence operations?
Answer. This administration takes Russia's malign influence
activities very seriously and has directed the Department to take a
number of actions to counter those activities. Consistent with the
President's direction, the Department participates in the National
Security Council process, which coordinates the administration's
responses to counter and blunt Russian malign influence. As part of
that process, the Department has participated in developing the
administration's National Security Strategy and other strategic plans
that detail and direct interagency actions to respond to Russian's
malign influence operations.
Moreover, the President has issued Executive Order 13848, Imposing
Certain Sanctions in the Event of Foreign Interference in a United
States Election, to counter and blunt foreign efforts to interfere in
or undermine public confidence in United States elections. Among other
things, the Executive Order directs the Director of National
Intelligence to assess any information indicating that a foreign
government acted with the intent or purpose of interfering in a Federal
election; directs the Attorney General to assess (in consultation with
the Secretary of Homeland Security) whether any such efforts materially
affected the security or integrity of either election or campaign
infrastructure; and directs the Secretary of the Treasury (in
consultation with the Attorney General, among others) to impose all
sanctions that might be appropriate in light of those assessments. The
Department has also participated in a number of specific responses to
Russian malign influence operations, some of which were administration-
directed, including sanctions targeting Russian individuals and
entities for malign influence operations, actions to call out and
confront Russian efforts to undermine the United States, and efforts to
strengthen our alliances and stand up to Russia's malign influence
across the globe.
Question 11. General Curtis Scaparrotti, the outgoing European
Commander, recently testified to the Armed Services Committee that U.S.
efforts to counter Russian influence operations still lacked
``effective unification across the interagency.'' Equally troubling was
his assessment that the United States has yet to develop ``a multi-
faceted strategy to counter Russia.''
Do you agree with General Scaparrotti's assessment that the U.S.
Government still lacks an ``effective unification'' among Federal
agencies? Do you agree with the need for a multi-faceted strategy to
counter Russia?
Answer. No, I do not agree that we lack ``effective unification
across the interagency'' when it comes to election interference. The
Department participates in several processes to coordinate Federal
responses to Russian malign influence. For example, the National
Security Council leads coordination of the U.S. Government's strategy
to counter malign foreign influence operations and campaigns, including
Russia's influence operations. As part of that process, the Department
has helped develop the administration's National Security Strategy and
other strategic plans that detail and direct interagency actions to
respond to Russian's malign influence operations. The Department also
participates in a State Department-led Active Measures Abroad Steering
Committee, which oversees an interagency strategy to counter Russian
propaganda, disinformation, and other malign influence efforts abroad.
The Department also is a member of a joint State Department-Defense
Department effort to develop a tailored strategy against the problem of
Russian influence operations in Europe. We also are involved in other
interagency groups that are working to integrate U.S. Government
efforts to combat influence efforts that target our political processes
and institutions, including elections. As the Department, the FBI, the
Office of the Director of National Intelligence, and DHS announced in a
joint statement shortly before the 2018 election, we ``have been
working in unprecedented ways to combat influence efforts.'' We will
continue to enhance our interagency unity and strategies going forward.
Question 12. Do you believe efforts across the government--
including the FBI's Foreign Influence Task Force--should be expanded in
the face of these ongoing threats?
Answer. The FBI's efforts to combat malign foreign influence
initially focused on the threat posed by Russia. In the lead up to
2020, the FBI has expanded its efforts to include the malign foreign
influence threats from China, Iran, and other global adversaries. The
FBI's Counterintelligence Division partnered with the Counterterrorism,
Criminal Investigative, and Cyber Divisions to advance the FBI's
strategy in countering, identifying, and defeating efforts by our
adversaries to undermine U.S. democratic institutions and to address
malign foreign influence targeting the U.S. that comes from around the
globe.
Question 13. Are our activities changing Putin's behavior, in your
assessment?
Answer. The FBI's Counterintelligence Division assesses that
Russia's intelligence services continue to use human and technical
sources to collect voluminous amounts of intelligence from the public
and private sectors, which informs Russia's influence activities,
broader foreign policy, military posture, and economic interests. The
Department defers to the Intelligence Community for assessments of any
impact of our activities on Putin's behavior.
special counsel's report--obstruction
Question 14. You testified that you do not know whether Special
Counsel Mueller supports your conclusion that President Trump did not
commit obstruction of justice. Did you ask Mr. Mueller whether he
supports your conclusion? If not, why not?
Answer. Former Special Counsel Mueller has made public statements
and testified before Congress on July 24, 2019. I would refer you to
Mr. Mueller's statements and testimony, which speak for themselves.
Question 15. Was your independent conclusion that the President did
not commit a crime based on the finding of the Mueller report or was it
based on the Department of Justice interpretation that a president
cannot be indicted?
Answer. During my hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee on
May 1, 2019, I stated that, although Deputy Attorney General Rod
Rosenstein and I ``disagreed with some of the Special Counsel's legal
theories and felt that some of the episodes examined did not amount to
obstruction as a matter of law, we accepted the Special Counsel's legal
framework for purposes of our analysis and evaluated the evidence as
presented by the Special Counsel in reaching our conclusion. We
concluded that the evidence developed during the Special Counsel's
investigation is not sufficient to establish that the President
committed an obstruction-of-justice offense.''
Question 16. What does it mean that the President was not
exonerated?
Answer. On April 18, 2019, I released to the public and provided to
Congress a public version of the confidential report prepared by
Special Counsel Mueller. In addition, I have made a minimally redacted
version of the Special Counsel's report available to certain
congressional leaders and staff. The public report speaks for itself.
mueller report composition
Question 17. Exactly how many pages are in the Special Counsel's
report? How many pages are in any attached summaries, tables or
appendices? Why have you kept this basic information from the public
and Congress?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 16 above.
peripheral third parties
Question 18. You wrote that you will redact ``information that
would unduly infringe on the reputational interests of peripheral third
parties.'' Please define ``peripheral third parties.'' Would that
include organizations described in criminal complaints, such as the
National Rifle Association?
Answer. It would defeat the purpose of redacting information that
might unduly infringe on the reputational interests of peripheral third
parties for me to give hints or suggestions about whose identity has
been redacted. In addition, I have made a minimally redacted version of
the Special Counsel's report available to certain congressional leaders
and staff.
affordable care act
Question 19. In Texas v. the United States, the Department of
Justice has taken a legal position that the Affordable Care Act,
including the protections for people with pre-existing conditions,
should be struck down. If DOJ's view prevails and these protections are
stripped away, the President says ``don't worry'' because Republicans
will reveal a plan after the 2020 election to fix the healthcare system
and restore these protections.
In taking its legal position, did DOJ also analyze what a ``win''
for the administration in court would mean in terms of enacting reforms
to the health system in the future? Did DOJ have any concern that its
legal position in the Texas v. United States case will result in a
decision that will limit the ability of this or future administrations
to pursue healthcare reform legislation?
Answer. This matter is the subject of ongoing litigation before the
Fifth Circuit. The Department filed its appellate brief on May 1, 2019,
which outlines the Department's position. On June 26, 2019, the court
ordered supplemental letter briefing, and the United States filed its
response on July 3, 2019. The court held argument on July 9, 2019, and
the panel has not yet issued a decision. Pursuant to longstanding
Department policy and practice, I cannot comment further on pending
litigation matters.
Question 20. Has DOJ analyzed any proposal from the administration
to ensure that it would stand up to legal challenge?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 19 above.
Question 21. Did DOJ (or other entities or persons in the
administration) provide any legal analysis of what protections people
with pre-existing conditions would have if the ACA were repealed and
the President fails to come through with his promised plan? If so, I
would request a copy of this legal analysis.
Answer. Please see my response to Question 19 above.
______
Questions Submitted by Senator Christopher A. Coons
special counsel's report
Question 1. There are redactions contained in the Special Counsel's
report on Russian interference in the 2016 presidential election that
was produced to Congress and the public.
1a. Did the Special Counsel's Office approve all of the redactions
in Special Counsel Mueller's report?
1b. Who worked on each set of redactions?
Answer. Attorneys at the Department of Justice worked with members
of the Special Counsel's team to determine what material would be
redacted from the report.
Question 2. An April 18 letter from Assistant Attorney General
Stephen E. Boyd states that the Chairmen and Ranking Members of the
House and Senate Judiciary Committees and Members of the ``Gang of
Eight'' will be permitted to look at a version of the Special Counsel's
report with all redactions removed except for the grand jury material.
2a. Why did you decide to limit review to just those members of
Congress?
Answer. Under applicable law, the Department was under no
obligation to provide the Special Counsel's confidential report to the
public, or to any Members of Congress. Nevertheless, I determined, in
the interests of transparency and in light of the considerable public
attention to this matter, to release a public version of the Special
Counsel's report and to provide certain members of Congress and their
staff with a minimally redacted version. In addition, I agreed to
provide access to the less redacted version of Volume I to members of
the House and Senate Intelligence Committees, as well as access to the
less redacted version of Volume II to members of the House and Senate
Judiciary Committees.
2b. Are the procedures outlined in the April 18 letter pursuant to
any specific Justice Department policy?
Answer. The procedures regarding review of the report were
determined by Department leadership after thoughtful consideration of
the sensitivity of some of the information and the potential effects of
its release on ongoing matters.
Question 3. During your hearing before this subcommittee, you said
Special Counsel Mueller did not ask you to make a determination about
the possible obstruction-of-justice offense described in the Special
Counsel's report. However, you provided your own conclusion on
obstruction in your March 24 letter because that is ``generally how the
Department of Justice works.'' At your April 18 press conference, you
reiterated that ``because the Special Counsel did not make [a decision
about the obstruction-of-justice offense], we felt the Department had
to.''
The Special Counsel's report clearly states that a decision was
made ``not to apply an approach that could potentially result in a
judgment that the President committed crimes'' and, thus, the Special
Counsel ``conducted a thorough factual investigation in order to
preserve the evidence when memories were fresh and documentary
materials were available.''
3a. Can you direct me to any portion of the Special Counsel's
report that indicates that Special Counsel Mueller intended for you to
reach a conclusion on the obstruction-of justice offense?
Answer. On April 18, 2019, I released to the public and provided to
Congress a public version of the confidential report prepared by
Special Counsel Mueller. In addition, I have made a minimally redacted
version of the Special Counsel's report available to certain
congressional leaders and staff. The public report speaks for itself.
3b. What are the bases for your conclusion on the obstruction-of-
justice offense?
Answer. During my testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee
on May 1, 2019, I discussed the obstruction-of-justice issue and stated
that although Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein and I ``disagreed
with some of the Special Counsel's legal theories and felt that some of
the episodes examined did not amount to obstruction as a matter of law,
we accepted the Special Counsel's legal framework for purposes of our
analysis and evaluated the evidence as presented by the Special Counsel
in reaching our conclusion. We conclude that the evidence developed
during the Special Counsel's investigation is not sufficient to
establish that the President committed an obstruction-of-justice
offense.''
3c. Special Counsel Mueller's report repeatedly makes clear that,
after a thorough investigation, he and his team did not have the
confidence to say that the President clearly did not commit obstruction
of justice. What additional evidence did you rely on when you concluded
that the President did not obstruct justice?
Answer. The determination that the Department must make in any
criminal matter is whether a crime could be proven beyond a reasonable
doubt to a jury. In assessing that question, Deputy Attorney General
Rod Rosenstein and I relied on the evidence outlined in the Special
Counsel's report.
Question 4. At your April 18 press conference, you were asked
whether the OLC opinion on indicting a sitting President ``had anything
to do with'' the Special Counsel's decision not to make a determination
on the obstruction-of-justice offense. You responded that Special
Counsel Mueller told you that he was not taking the position that ``he
would have found a crime, but for the existence of the OLC opinion.''
Yet, in the Special Counsel's report, he lists the OLC opinion as the
first consideration that guided his obstruction-of-justice
investigation. Do you agree that the American people would have better
understood the Special Counsel's reasons for not making a traditional
prosecutorial judgment if you had included Special Counsel Mueller's
four considerations that guided the investigation in your March 24
letter?
Answer. As I made clear in my March 29, 2019 letter, my earlier
March 24, 2019 letter was not intended to summarize the Special
Counsel's report but did describe its principal conclusions. On April
18, 2019, I released to the public and provided to Congress the public
version of the confidential report prepared by Special Counsel Mueller.
In addition, I have made a minimally redacted version of the Special
Counsel's report available to certain congressional leaders and staff.
The public report speaks for itself.
Question 5. When I asked you during the subcommittee hearing last
week whether anyone outside the Justice Department, particularly anyone
in the White House, had seen all or portions of the Special Counsel's
report or had been briefed on the report, you declined to answer until
the report had been released.
5a. Please list every individual outside the Justice Department who
saw the report or was briefed on the report prior its release to the
public on April 18.
Answer. In my April 18, 2019, letter to the Chairs and Ranking
Members of the Senate Judiciary Committee and the House Judiciary
Committee, I described the process by which the Department prepared the
Special Counsel's report for public release and provided details as to
its review by individuals outside the Department prior to release. I
would refer to you to that description.
5b. On what date did each person receive the report?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 5(a) above and my April
18, 2019, letter to the Chairmen and Ranking Members of the Senate
Judiciary Committee and the House Judiciary Committee.
5c. What was the basis for disclosure of the report to each person?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 5(a) above and my April
18, 2019, letter to the Chairs and Ranking Members of the Senate
Judiciary Committee and the House Judiciary Committee.
Question 6. In your March 24 letter, you quoted a portion of the
Special Counsel's report that states ``while this report does not
conclude that the President committed a crime, it also does not
exonerate him.'' Yet, you did not include the sentences preceding that
quotation: ``[I]f we had confidence after a thorough investigation of
the facts that the President clearly did not commit obstruction of
justice, we would so state. Based on the facts and the applicable legal
standards, however, we are unable to reach that judgment.'' Why did you
choose not to include that quotation in your March 24 letter?
Answer. As required by 28 C.F.R. Sec. 600.9(a)(3), on March 22,
2019, I sent a letter to the Chairman and Ranking Member of the Senate
Judiciary Committee and House Judiciary Committee notifying them that
Special Counsel Mueller had concluded his investigation of Russian
interference in the 2016 election and related matters and submitted to
me his ``confidential report explaining the prosecution or declination
decisions'' he reached, as required by 28 C.F.R. Sec. 600.8(c). On
March 24, 2019, I sent a subsequent letter to the Chairman and Ranking
Member of the Senate Judiciary Committee and House Judiciary Committee
advising them of the ``principal conclusions'' reached by the Special
Counsel and updating them on the status of the Department's review of
the report. My letter speaks for itself.
Question 7. During your remarks at your April 18 press conference,
you stated that ``the White House fully cooperated with the Special
Counsel's investigation.'' Appendix C of the Special Counsel's report
states that the investigators sought to interview the President ``for
more than a year,'' yet, the President was never interviewed. The
President instead submitted written responses, which were insufficient
``in several respects.'' The Special Counsel's Office again requested
to interview the President, and the President again declined. The
Special Counsel decided not to issue a subpoena for the President's
testimony only because of the substantial delay it would cause. Why do
you consider the President's refusal to provide oral testimony and his
inadequate written responses to be full cooperation?
Answer. The public report describes the steps that the White House
took to cooperate with the Special Counsel's investigation and speaks
for itself.
Question 8. In your prepared remarks at your April 18 press
conference, you said that you and the Deputy Attorney General
``disagreed with some of the Special Counsel's legal theories.'' What
are those disagreements?
Answer. Pursuant to longstanding Department policies and practice,
I will not comment further on these deliberative, pre-decisional
internal discussions.
2016 counterintelligence investigation into the trump campaign
Question 9. During the hearing, you testified that you are
reviewing the genesis of the 2016 counterintelligence investigation
into the Trump campaign.
9a. Who is involved in that review?
Answer. As the Department of Justice has previously announced, a
team led by U.S. Attorney John Durham is examining the origins of the
U.S. counterintelligence probe of the Trump 2016 presidential campaign.
9b. When do you expect the review to be completed?
Answer. Mr. Durham is working expeditiously, but I do not have an
anticipated deadline for the completion of his review.
9c. Have you discussed the review with President Trump or other
White House officials?
Answer. Pursuant to longstanding Department and Executive Branch
policies and practices, I am unable to comment on any White House
communications.
9d. Will you share the findings of your review with Congress?
Answer. As with the findings of Special Counsel Mueller's
investigation, I believe that there is a strong public interest in the
public and Congress learning about the results of Mr. Durham's work. I
am therefore committed to making public as much information as
possible, consistent with applicable laws and Department policies. Upon
completion of Mr. Durham's review, Congress will be appropriately
briefed.
9e. What is the factual basis for your concern that unauthorized
surveillance of the Trump campaign occurred?
Answer. Given that Mr. Durham's work is ongoing, I do not believe
it would be appropriate to comment on the details at this time. As
stated above, Congress will be appropriate briefed upon completion of
Mr. Durham's review.
drug trafficking
Question 10. The fiscal year 2020 funding request, like the fiscal
year 2019 request, transfers the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas
program from the Office of National Drug Control Policy to the Drug
Enforcement Administration. When ONDCP is already providing needed
assistance to combat the scourge of addiction, why do you recommend
this proposed change?
Answer. The administration believes that moving the High Intensity
Drug Trafficking Areas (HIDTA) program from ONDCP to DEA would allow
the program to be more closely integrated with DEA, the component
charged with enforcing the Nation's drug trafficking laws. The
administration anticipates the program will remain largely the same as
it is today, but will benefit from this close integration.
background checks for firearm purchases
Question 11. My home community of Wilmington, Delaware is working
to reduce gun violence, and I want to identify ways that the Federal
Government can help local law enforcement confront this challenge. I
have worked with Sen. Toomey and others to introduce the NICS Denial
Notification Act (S. 875), which requires the Federal Government to
notify State and local law enforcement when someone fails a background
check while trying to purchase a firearm. Do you agree that it would
help local law enforcement to know when a prohibited person tried to
buy a gun?
Answer. The sharing of investigative intelligence among law
enforcement agencies is helpful in preventing and prosecuting crime,
specifically with regards to a prohibited person attempting to purchase
a firearm. The Department would be happy to review your draft
legislation.
public safety partnership
Question 12. In 2018, the National Public Safety Partnership only
operated in five cities. Will the program be expanded in 2019 or 2020?
Answer. The National Public Safety Partnership (PSP) is a strategic
initiative geared at helping cities develop and implement programs and
procedures intended to reduce violent crime. It is a 3-year commitment
by the Department to provide resources to help cities diagnose where
crime is highest and to find, arrest, and prosecute violent criminals.
Several participating cities have already seen dramatic reductions in
violent crime over the past 2 years. As we continue to expand this
program annually to more cities across America, including planned
additions in fiscal year 2020, we are determined to replicate that
success.
In 2018, 15 PSP sites were operational. Five new cities were
selected as 2018 PSP sites, and the 10 PSP sites that were added in
2017 entered their second year of the partnership. To date, 31 cities
have participated in the program with the addition of 10 new sites in
fiscal year 2019 I announced last month including: Anniston, Alabama,
Oxford, Alabama, Anchorage, Alaska, Davenport, Iowa, Wichita, Kansas,
Baton Rouge, Louisiana, Baltimore, Maryland, Cleveland, Ohio, Amarillo,
Texas, and Harris County, Texas.
first step act
Question 13. Though the President's fiscal year 2020 budget
dramatically underfunds the First Step Act, earlier this month, the
President said that his administration ``intends to fully fund and
implement'' the First Step Act.
13a. Have you discussed full funding for the First Step Act with
the President?
Answer. I am not in a position to disclose any pre-decisional
deliberations regarding the President's Budget.
13b. Will you commit to taking all necessary steps to fully
implement the First Step Act?
Answer. The Department has been and continues to diligently work to
fully implement the First Step Act.
13c. What is the Department's current progress on creating the risk
and needs assessment tool?
Answer. The Department published the First Step Act Risk and Needs
Assessment System on July 19, 2019, meeting a key requirement of the
First Step Act. At that time, the Department announced a 45-day public
comment period and encouraged experts, practitioners, advocates,
academics, and others to comment on the report so that the Department
could build the best and most fair tool possible. On September 10th and
11th, NIJ hosted two listening sessions in response to the release of
PATTERN. Stakeholders provided public comment on the risk and needs
assessment as well as DOJ's implementation of the First Step Act
(``FSA''). In response to the release of PATTERN, the 45-day public
comments period, and the listening sessions, NIJ received approximately
20 statements from external stakeholders about the FSA, and close to
175 emailed comments/statements.
13d. What actions, beyond implementing the First Step Act, will the
Department take under your leadership to increase fairness in our
criminal justice system as a whole and in prison sentencing
specifically?
Answer. Following the development of the new Risk and Needs
Assessment required under the First Step Act, the Department has
actively sought comments from experts, practitioners, advocates, and
academics. The Department will consider this feedback, along with
results from our internal evaluation efforts, in determining how to
continue to protect fairness in the criminal justice system.
legal services corporation
Question 14. For the third year in a row, President Trump's budget
request proposes to eliminate all Federal funding for the Legal
Services Corporation.
14a. Is Federal support for the Legal Services Corporation
important in order to achieve greater access to justice for Americans?
Answer. As you know, the Legal Services Corporation (LSC) is not
part of the Department of Justice. Nonetheless, the fiscal year 2020
President's Budget seeks $18 million for the LSC. The Budget seeks to
end the one-size-fits-all model of providing legal services through a
single Federal grant program, the LSC. This change will encourage non-
profit organizations, businesses, law firms, and religious institutions
to develop new models for providing legal aid, such as pro bono work,
law school clinics, and innovative technologies. This puts more control
in the hands of State and local governments that better understand the
needs of their communities.
14b. Do you support continued Federal funding for the Legal
Services Corporation?
Answer. Please see my response to Question 14(a) above.
14c. As head of the U.S. Department of Justice, what actions will
you take to ensure that low income Americans have greater access to
justice?
Answer. The Department is committed to helping the justice system
efficiently deliver outcomes that are fair and accessible to all,
irrespective of wealth and status. The Department of Justice works
internally, across Federal agencies, and with State, local, and Tribal
justice system stakeholders to improve justice delivery systems. The
Department's work to ensure justice for all is guided by three
principles: (1) Promoting Accessibility--eliminating barriers that
prevent people from understanding and exercising their rights; (2)
Ensuring Fairness--delivering fair and just outcomes for all parties,
including those facing financial and other disadvantages; and (3)
Increasing Efficiency--delivering fair and just outcomes effectively,
without waste or duplication.
As just one example of these efforts, in response to a public
safety crisis in rural Alaska, the Department recently authorized more
than $10 million in immediate funding to support police in Alaska
Native villages and additional resources to support child advocacy
centers in rural hubs, expanding wrap-around services, forensic
interviews, and medical exams for child victims. See https://
www.justice.gov/opa/pr/attorney-general-william-p-barr-announces-
emergency-funding-address-public-safety-crisis. In addition, the
Department coordinated a week of events recognizing World Elder Abuse
Awareness Day on June 15, which is dedicated to raising awareness about
the millions of older adults who experience elder abuse, neglect, and
financial exploitation. On October 18, the Department published the
Attorney General's annual report to Congress on its activities to
combat elder fraud and abuse, which highlights a record-breaking number
of enforcement actions in the United States and abroad, as well as
outreach efforts to protect seniors. See https://www.justice.gov/file/
1211066/download. The Department of Justice is committed to defending
the vulnerable and obtaining justice for those who have been targeted.
religious liberty task force
Question 15. In July 2018, then-Attorney General Sessions announced
the creation of a ``religious liberty task force'' to assist the
Justice Department with the implementation of the October 2017 Guidance
on Federal Law Protections for Religious Liberty.
15a. Does the ``religious liberty task force'' remain in existence?
Answer. Yes.
15b. If so, who are the members of the task force?
Answer. As Attorney General, I serve as chair of the Religious
Liberty Task Force. The Task Force membership also includes the
Principal Deputy Associate Attorney General, the Assistant Attorney
General for the Office of Legal Policy, and a representative from the
Office of the Deputy Attorney General. Further, the Task Force includes
the heads of the components named in the Attorney General's Memorandum
establishing the Task Force, joined by the U.S. Attorney for the
Northern District of Texas, the head of the Office of Justice Programs,
and two additional Department employees designated by the Attorney
General.
15c. What are the task force's key priorities?
Answer. The Task Force's key priority is to ensure the Department
implements the Attorney General's Memorandum ``Federal Law Protections
for Religious Liberty,'' 82 Fed. Reg. 49668 (October 26, 2017), by
ensuring that all Department components are upholding that guidance in
the cases they bring and defend, the arguments they make in court, the
policies and regulations they adopt, and the conduct of their
operations.
SUBCOMMITTEE RECESS
Senator Moran. Subcommittee now stands in recess.
[Whereupon, at 12:01 p.m., Wednesday, April 10, the
subcommittee was recessed, to reconvene subject to the call of
the Chair.]
